name: Bobbi Hutchins, PhD(c)
headline: AI Strategist | Chief AI and Marketing Officer | P...
text_content:
Australia's "Great Firewall" for teens has officially gone live. It's a global first, and the tech world is watching with bated breath. But peel back the headlines, and it's clear to see it's a policy as riddled with holes as it is well intentioned.
Here's my TL;DR version of what is and isn't happening, what's exempt, and the new industries this ban is about to inadvertently create.
1. The "Safe" List (Or, what isn't banned)
The government has drawn a line in the sand... but it's a total zig-zag.
TikTok, Instagram, Snapchat, Reddit, and X are gone. But a substantial proportion of the digital playground remains a no-go zone-free zone.
Messaging is "Safe": WhatsApp and Messenger Kids are exempt. 👀
Gaming is "Safe": Roblox, Fortnite, and Discord—platforms where in real life millions of kids primarily "hang out" with friends (and sometimes experience truly unmoderated anarchy)—are broadly exempt or in the grey zone.
"Kids" versions are safe (presumably) : YouTube Kids and Google Classroom.
The Irony: You can't scroll TikTok, but can arguably spend 6 hours in a Discord voice chat or a Roblox server. The lines between "social media" and "gaming" are 2010's thinking in a 2025 world.
2. The New Industries This Will Breed
Whenever you build a wall, you create a market for ladders. This is an economic stimulus package for two very specific industries:
The Compliance Complex: Prepare for a cottage industry in "Age Assurance" tech. Companies like K-ID and Yoti (pronounced "yo-tee") will become the new gatekeepers. Every platform now needs expensive, privacy invasive biometric tools to scan faces and check IDs.
The Evasion Economy: This is the darker side. We are about to see a "grey market" mushroom in size.
VPNs: "How to spoof your location to Norway" will be the new "how to top search term for every Australian 15-year-old.
Account Brokering: Expect to see a secondary market for "verified" 16+ accounts.
Alt-Platforms: Expect kids to already be jumping to platforms like Yope and Lemon8 (owned by ByteDance) that no one is regulating yet... until the government plays whack-a-mole and bans those too.
3. The Deeper Issue
This is the most important part in my opinion. The ban illuminates a terrifying dependence on "Safety Theater." It lets the government say, "We fixed it" by putting shiny salve on a gory, open wound.
Banning the platforms with safety teams, parental controls, and moderation (like Instagram) just to replace them with messaging apps and fringe sites where no one is watching. It's sweeping our failures to teach digital literacy and the uncomfortable truth that legislation is not parenting under the rug.
We aren't fixing the mental health crisis, we are just moving the conversation to a room where we can no longer hear it.

name: Danielle Sanchez
headline: You Can Be AI-Driven AND Human-first. Join me & 5k others...
text_content:
This sounds like a contradiction but,
you can build authentic authority with AI.
AI almost feels synonymous to "fake".
And most of the time, it is.
Yet, I'm increasing finding that it's possible to be authentic while using it.
Let's me share two personal examples.
I'm using it to write a book right now. Ken Freire and I cohosted nearly two dozen podcasts strategically to have enough content into book chapters.
I'm merely asking Claude to do the work of a ghost writer and smooth out the transcript into a working chapter.
The chapters are surprisingly good. It's completely authentic without adding anything more, though it certainly strategically left some pieces out or clipped pieces from different parts of the conversation together.
It's authentic AI.
I've also used ChatGPT and Suno recently to put together a personal album for my wife. I went back through a number of meaningful events in the first year of our relationship, told ChatGPT the stories, had it write the lyrics, and had Suno make the music.
Is it the same as me writing and recording it myself? No.
Did it make her cry and laugh as we relived that season of our lives together? Yes.
It's authentic AI.
There are dozens of ways you can make this work. It all depends on the inputs you give it and the prompts you guide it with along the way.
This will be the standard way of doing things in a few years.
Just wait.
#Danche

name: Anita Moorthy
headline: Co-Founder & CMO @RockSall | The modern in...
text_content:
Three CMOs I respect are all talking about your people becoming a lever for your brand:
1. Kieran Flanagan (HubSpot SVP):
“I’ve spent time with multiple marketing teams this year who have all shifted their focus to growing the personal channels of their exec teams.”
2. Kyle Lacy (CMO, Docebo):
“There is no time. You should always be thinking about doing this. I don't care if you are series A or a publicly traded company.”
3. Emily Kramer (Founder, MKT1):
“LinkedIn is now the go-to platform for founders and execs to build an audience, and we’ve entered the age of executive LinkedInfluence.”
It's really no surprise they are saying this. Human expertise is what's going to cut through all the AI noise. Real people with real stories.
So why aren't more people getting their best people engaging on social?
I hear two objections:
1) "I don't have time"
Fair point. Some people genuinely want to do this but struggle to find the time. Others just... don't want to. Find the people on the team that want to.
2) "What if they leave and take their audience?"
Fair point. Build up 3-4 voices across your team. It spreads the risk and it's better for your overall reach too.
Here's how you can get this going in your company:
1. Find the right person
Look for someone who genuinely want to do this AND have direct credibility with your ICP.
2. Get them engaging (just 10 minutes a day)
Before they ever post anything, have them spend a few minutes commenting on posts from people in your industry. It's low-pressure, keeps them in the loop, and starts putting them in front of your audience.
3. Make creating really easy for them
Most people fail because creating content feels like work. So don't make them write posts. Instead:
- Let them send voice memos with their insights while commuting.
- Have a Slack channel where they drop random ideas
- Let the marketing team turns it into actual posts
This way you're not asking them to become content creators. You're just capturing what they already know.
I think the companies figuring this out right now are going to be way ahead in a year or two.
How many of you are doing this?
Where are you in your journey and what's biggest challenge you are having?

name: Chiara Gallese, Ph.D.
headline: Award-Winning Researcher | AI Law & Ethics,...
text_content:
Imagine waking up tomorrow and realising your entire digital presence has been wiped out.
That's the story that played out last week, just on a much bigger scale.
Two days ago, X removed the European Commission's advertising account.
Not a random creator.
Not a business.
A government institution.
And it happened days after they were fined €120 million for breaking transparency rules.
I've advised enough teams on platform risk to know this:
Most people underestimate how fragile their digital presence really is.
Your entire online footprint – your audience, your distribution, your content – exists on platforms that can shut the door without warning.
No explanation.
No appeal.
No conversation.
And no compensation of the damages they caused.
And if they can do it to a government, imagine the leverage they hold over you.
Think about it: this is textbook operational risk.
Whether you're a founder, creator, leader, or marketer, you need to take this seriously.
Because you are building your business on rented land.
And the landlord is getting less predictable by the month.
Remember: most people only realise they're in trouble after they've lost everything they built.
What actually happened:
The EU fined X €120 million for violating digital transparency regulations (misleading verification badges, hiding ad data, blocker researcher access).
X’s response? Delete their account.
They accused the Commission of "exploiting" their ad system to artificially boost a post about the fine.
A corporation just punished a regulatory body for doing its job.
What most people don't want to hear:
If your primary distribution sits inside one platform, you don't own a business.
You own a dependency.
The smartest operators I know do three things extremely well:
1. They own their data
Email lists. Websites. Direct relationships.
Platforms are megaphones, not foundations.
You control what you own.
2. They diversify their presence
If one platform pulls the plug, the system keeps running.
LinkedIn. Newsletter. Blog. Community.
Never let a single company hold your entire audience hostage.
3. They build defensibility into their digital identity
Portable data. Clear rights. Transparent governance.
Support decentralized alternatives where you control your identity (Mastodon, Bluesky, owned platforms).
You deserve a digital presence that isn't dependent on a billionaire's mood.
So, consider this:
Your voice shouldn't exist at the pleasure of shareholders.
Your reach shouldn't disappear because you criticized the platform.
Your years of work shouldn't vanish with one decision you can't appeal.
Most people won't take this seriously until it happens to them.
By then, it's too late.
If you vanished from your main platform tomorrow, would you still have a business?
Think about it today. Not tomorrow. And that's the real problem.
Follow me Chiara Gallese, Ph.D.  for more on AI & Tech risks
[Image/Video Placeholder]

name: Petra Caputa
headline: CEO at Databox
text_content:
These days, most buyers are learning about products and services way before they visit a company's website, yet most companies start measuring their funnel with website traffic.
There have been big changes to the way buyers buy in the last year or two:
- They use LLMs to thoroughly research solutions and vendors, ONLY visiting the vendor's website when they're ready to convert into a lead.
- They use social media (LinkedIn, youtube, podcasts, reddit, etc) to learn about new ways of solving problems. Once they find someone interesting, they follow companies (and the people from those companies) to learn over time. ONLY when they're ready to convert into a lead or trial do they visit the websites of those companies.
- They ask their peers in communities with other peers to get recommendations on what are the best companies to work with. They visit those company's websites ONLY once they've decided to learn more.
- They consume even long-form content from companies without ever visiting the company's website: youtube, publishing video/podcasts, newsletters, then they're website once... (you get the idea).
So, if a company is doing marketing correctly by actively publishing/engaging on social, optimizing for LLMs, publishing video/podcasts/newsletters, then they're measuring awareness & nurturing prospects before they ever visit their website.
But are these companies measuring the impact of these things?
We weren't. We've been marketing this way for years.
However, we really didn't have a good system to measure awareness, reach & engagement. So, the team recently put this funnel chart together. (See below.)
While I was pushing the marketing team for awhile to measure awareness, reach & engagement on social media, I hadn't thought of putting it all on one big funnel.
The chart uses our data calculations feature to add metrics together from different places for these metrics:
1️⃣ Awareness: impressions across social media sites, ad impressions, etc.
2️⃣ Reach: unique people we're reaching across those same platforms.
3️⃣ Engagement: actions taken by people. Things like likes, comments, shares, clicking on a LinkedIn post, clicking on a link from a social site, etc.
4️⃣ New contacts: every new contact we add in HubSpot. This includes people converting on the website, people we chat with on social, as well as contacts our sales team adds, etc. We can assume that we're somehow engaging with these people or trying to.
The funnel gets simple from there: people signing up for our trial, becoming a deal, buying, etc.
But now that we can see aggregate impressions, reach & engagement, we can experiment with new things to see what moves the needle.
We can also start measuring correlation between these metrics & our sales to ensure that our improvements in awareness, reach and engagement flows through to new customer acquisition.
How are you measuring this stuff? (Or are you still calling them vanity metrics?)

headline: Founder @ CopyTribe and Profitable Freela...
text_content:
You open an email from a colleague... and UGH. Another ChatGPT wordfest.
It feels icky. Unhuman.
With LLMs everywhere, that's the reality. 😐
Emails are clearer, more polished than ever — and they've also lost their soul, that invisible thread connecting two living, thinking beings.
That's why, a few years ago, I started sending personal video replies instead of emails whenever possible using CopyTribe — and the results were striking.
Faster decisions. Higher conversion. Deeper trust.
In a video, they hear your voice, see you speaking directly to them. It creates a connection that text cannot match.
We've gotten this kind of feedback:
"Your video made me feel like you actually cared about MY situation. Not just about making a sale."
Videos take more time (and energy!) upfront. But if you're selling something high-ticket and someone reaches out with questions, a 2-3 minute Loom can make all the difference. Address their concerns. Show them you're a real human who cares.
It might be the thing that tips them from "thinking about it" to "I'm in."

Virksomhedens CFO installerede et gratis Chrome-plugin. 14 dage senere lå kundedatabasen til salg på Dark Web.
Han tænkte slet ikke over det. For plugin’et ville jo spare ham tid på Chrome Web Store med fine anmeldelser.
Kun få klik, og så var det installeret.
IT-afdelingen blev ikke spurgt.
Og det virkede!
To uger senere begyndte der at ske mærkelige ting:
Konkurrenter nævnte detaljer om jeres kunder, de ikke burde kende til.
Det viste sig, at pluginnet sendte data ud af huset.
Kundelisten var nu eksponeret online, og klar til hvem som helst med onde hensigter.
Lyder det ekstremt?
Måske. Men det sker oftere, end du tror.
Velkommen til 2025, hvor supply-chain-angreb og ondsindet open source-code er hverdag.
Når vi bruger AI-modeller og open source-software, bygger vi ovenpå tusindvis af kode-biblioteker og plugins.
Hvis ét led er svagt, kan det lamme hele driften. Også selvom I aldrig har hørt om PyTorch.
🔐 Sådan beskytter du din virksomhed bedre:
• Lav en politik for brug af software. Også AI, software-biblioteker og plugins.
• Scan jeres open source-modeller for skjult kode, før de tages i brug.
• Begræns installation af plugins og overvåg systemrettigheder.
• Inkludér AI og browser-udvidelser i risikovurderinger.
• Kortlæg jeres forsyningskæde, og patch hurtigt!
IT-sikkerhed starter ikke i serverrummet. Den starter i ledelsen.
Tager I ansvar nu, eller venter I, til det går galt? 🫠
Hvornår har I sidst fået foretaget en grundig IT-sikkerhed screening?

headline: We help B2B service businesses who Depend...
text_content:
Mark my words.
Don't use AI for creative tasks like writing.
If you rely on it for 5 years from now when your critical thinking faculties will have vanished, your brain is mush and you'll be a clueless, unemployable ADD-riddled mess who cannot even write a correct English sentence that's longer than "Be kind."
Use AI for:
• initial research
• orienting yourself in a new field of knowledge
• extracting key info from large volumes of data
• and a ton of other clerical, lower value activity.
But do NOT use it for writing, especially long form.
Writing is crystallized thinking.
If you stop writing, your thinking will become muddled, circular and blunt.
Don't outsource your key moneymaker.

headline: Creative marketing leader — bringing clarity and bold ideas t...

Why do we HAVE TO implement AI...?
This year, everything in marketing seems wrapped in a layer of productivity and acceleration. Yeah, I know that's every year. But this year in particular feels like marketing and content teams became Hogwarts House Elves...
So - quick story - at this year's Executive Forum at Content Marketing World, we had a fascinating discussion on AI, and I asked what I thought was a simple question: "Why do we HAVE to implement AI...?"
Almost every answer fell into one of two buckets: fear or guilt.
"If we don't, we'll fall behind." "If we don't, we're not doing our jobs." "If we don't... well... the innovation convention gets stuffed in the glove compartment.
Now, I'm not saying those things aren't true. They might be.
But I've seen this point of view in so many marketing teams lately - this rush to the finish line keeping noses down and somehow the hill gets steeper.)
Coming out of the holiday weekend, I've been thinking a lot about gratitude -as one does. Not the big, performative kind, but the quiet kind that grounds you. The kind that nudges you and says:
"What eyes am I using to see this moment?"
We all look through different lenses: the rushed lens, the cynical lens, the overwhelmed lens, the "I'm not doing enough" lens.
Lately - both in business and, lets face it, life - I've found myself reaching for the lens of gratitude whenever I can. And that one... well, it changes not just what I see, but the speed at which I see it.
It reminded me of a client this year who embodies this idea far better than I do. I tell his story in the longer article, which I've linked in the first comment.
Albert Schweitzer once wrote: "I always think that we all live, spiritually, by what others have given us in the significant hours of our life."
This year, with all the speed, struggle, and strange new possibilities, I'm choosing to look at those significant hours through the lens of gratitude.
And I hope you will too.
[Image/Video Placeholder]

I've seen a handful of posts today where recruiters say not having a LI profile is a disqualifying ding if someone applies for a job. An “I will not engage with someone who has no LinkedIn profile” kind of stance.
I’d like to ask folks to go easy on that assumption.
Many folks tapped out of social media and anything resembling it for a variety of reasons including security, privacy, and a general lack of interest. Judging from some of the interactions I’ve seen on here, they may have a point.
Now, I understand how some profiles might look sketchy, or set some alarm bells ringing, and that is fair. But I believe the absence of a profile should not in itself be an immediate Do Not Engage.
What if you weren’t good at searching and simply didn’t find them? Is a LinkedIn profile a necessity in today’s job market? I Vehemently say “NO!”
Just because lots of people live their lives on LinkedIn doesn’t mean all good candidates need to.
Please be careful in how you disqualify people, okay?

And that's EXPLICIT intent, based on the next action for the AUDIENCE.
It's NOT whatever inferred intent you want it to be as a marketer (and let's be honest... we always want it to be buy-intent 🙃 ).
Your thought leadership content should drive trust- and learn-intent outcomes.
Your product content should drive buy- and use-intent outcomes.
Your support forums and documentation should drive help-intent outcomes.
Draft accordingly.
CTA transparently.
Measure accurately.
Build trust and drive revenue 👇✨

headline: I help B2B tech execs build their brands on Li...
text_content:
Is it just me or is ChatGPT getting dumber? 2 times in the last week, I’ve had to explain really simple things that it couldn’t figure out on its own.
Example 1:
I was writing a year-end recap for a client. To get organized, I gave ChatGPT a list of blog post URLs and asked for summaries. First it said it can’t read URLs. I reminded it that it can, and in fact, it does it all the time for me.
It said “Oh, right” and gave me the summaries. Except they were all made up.
Literally nothing was accurate. So I asked where the information came from, and it said the posts’ metadata, not the content itself. But I checked the metadata, and nothing lined up there either.
Folks, ChatGPT was gaslighting me.
Eventually I had to copy and paste each post’s text in. I don’t think it saved me any time.
Example 2:
I uploaded a CSV file containing the text of all my LinkedIn posts and asked for an analysis. ChatGPT told me it couldn't read it, and that I should instead upload a CSV file containing the text of all my LinkedIn posts.
Which, of course, is exactly what I had just done.
I had to tell it which column the post text was in, and then it was able to conduct the analysis. But the CSV only had 6 columns. It couldn't figure that out on its own?
How am I supposed to trust AI's output and analysis when it can't do basic reading comprehension?

name: Amy Webb
headline: CEO of FTSG • Global Leader in Strategic Foresight • Quantit...
text_content:
Next year, you'll see the rise of unlimited labor.
But first, some context.
In 1928, a humanoid robot named Eric stood up, sat down, and delivered a speech. In 2013, Boston Dynamics introduced Atlas, a six-foot-two robot that could walk, run, and jump. Both moments were hailed as the dawn of the robot age.
A century later, we don't have humanoid robot butlers. We have cats riding Roombas.
The gap isn't mechanical. It's cognitive.
For robots to act in the physical world, they must see, understand, and adapt. They need the equivalent of human context awareness: the ability to process multimodal information and turn it into action. Until recently, that barrier was too high.
In 2026, that barrier will start collapsing.
Researchers are combining data from human motion, teleoperation, and visual archives—teaching machines to act by watching us act. When Google DeepMind trained a robot to play table tennis, it didn't just code the rules. It learned a shared signal: a physical Turing moment for robotics, where dexterity, intuition, and embodied intelligence move from research to reality.
This is setting up a “ChatGPT moment” for the physical world.
NVIDIA is openly betting on an AI-driven robot workforce as a core engine of U.S. re-industrialization. This year saw forecasts robots filling over half a million manufacturing roles. Amazon is pushing Parallel with Blue Jay, a network of automated warehouses, Diligent Robotics on hospital support, Johnson & Johnson on surgical robotics, and Figure AI on humanoid fleets for factories and eventually the home.
Amazon is pushing in Parallel with Blue Jay, a network of automated robotic arms designed to move packages faster and at lower cost, with a clear trajectory toward less human labor. Elon Musk claims his Optimus robots will achieve “five times the productivity of a person per year.”
But humanoid robots aren't really what's coming en masse.
Behind them will be millions of non-humanlike robots distributed across science labs, construction sites, logistics centers, farms, and janitorial stations and just about everywhere else. Specialized. Autonomous. Tireless.
For the second time in modern history, technology isn't offering tools for people to work. It's offering unlimited labor itself.
The question ahead of us isn't whether robots will replace jobs.
The question is who will own the labor once they do.
#BigIdeas2026

What if you already know the answer, but you don't trust yourself enough to act on it?
Maybe it's asking for advice you don't really need—hoping someone will confirm what you already know but don't yet trust.
Or perhaps it's that moment when you go against your gut feeling because someone else "probably knows better."
It could be the decisions you make to please others, the boundaries you don't set because you fear being wrong, or the constant second-guessing that keeps you spinning in circles.
And the cost?
We stay stuck, exhausted, and disconnected from our own inner compass.
In a world that won't slow down, where yesterday's certainties become tomorrow's questions, we're constantly looking outside ourselves for answers.
What if the answer isn't out there at all—but in learning to trust yourself when you don't have all the answers?
Check out my latest Pause on This thought and let me know when you find yourself outsourcing your inner knowing.
#wisdom #powerpausing #leadfromtheinsideout #trust #selfempowerment

text_content:
Are you using “delve” more often in your writing?
Lots of scientists are.
So are YouTubers.
As more rely on AI to write posts and scripts, it’s changing how we communicate with one another.
My takeaway: our language is getting more bland and homogenous, which ultimately = boring.
Clarity is lost.
Personality is lost.
From NY Times writer Sam Kriss:
A Max Planck Institute study of 360,000 YouTube videos found human speakers increasingly using AI-like phrasing, suggesting that AI's rhetorical tics are already feeding back into human speech.
AI prose has developed a distinctive, overfitted style marked by em dashes, triplets, elevated diction, and spectral metaphors that now appears across journalism, fiction, and corporate communications.
PubMed abstracts saw a 2,700% increase in the word "delves" after 2022, alongside spikes in terms like "intricate," "tapestry," and "meticulous."
That said, if you always used "delve" a lot, or em dashes, I say, carry on!
BTW, found this in the Future Forward newsletter – always a good read from Matthew Berman and team.

text_content:
Is there an AI bubble? This is a conversation that keeps coming up, and it's relevant to your personal investing decisions, and your career choices.
[The AI Show Episode 183]: AI Job Automation, Is There an AI Bubble?, AI Political Divides,...
podcast.smarterx.ai
This was a main topic on ep 183 of The Artificial Intelligence Show. Here are a few notes of what I shared:
You have to consider your own position from a personal investing perspective, but also from a career and business perspective.
What is your long-term thesis on AI?
What is your level of conviction?
What is your appetite for risk?
For me, I bet everything personally and professionally starting in 2016 that AI would change the world. That every business in every industry would be AI Native, AI Emergent or obsolete.
I bet on the companies that I thought were best positioned to grow when demand for intelligence scaled, and I built my own companies to help professionals and businesses accelerate their understanding and transformation.
I believe we are still on the leading edge of an intelligence explosion.
That does not mean that every AI company survives.
There will be winners and losers.
There will be ups and downs.
There will be variables that are out of our control that will impact the markets, and AI progress, in the months and years ahead.
What Accelerates AI Progress:
- Algorithmic breakthroughs
- Clean energy abundance (i.e. wind, solar, nuclear fission)
- More efficient training and inference (e.g. smaller models, targeted search and retrieval in models like o1, brains, faster chips)
- Cost of intelligence declines at a rapid rate
- Energy breakthroughs (e.g. nuclear fusion)
- Greater network and data security to reduce threats and increase trust
- Infrastructure investments (e.g. upgraded and expanded electrical grids, more data centers)
- Massive government funding (e.g. Apollo-type programs)
- More compute capacity (i.e. more chips and fabs, plus more resilient chip supply chain)
- New scaling laws
- Other scientific breakthroughs (e.g. metacognition, quantum computing, new physics)
What Slows AI Progress:
- Breakdown in the AI compute supply chain through natural (e.g. earthquakes, hurricanes) or human (e.g. physical or cyber sabotage) forces
- Catastrophic events blamed on AI
- Lack of adoption by enterprises
- Landmark IP lawsuits that impact access to training data and model outputs
- Restrictive laws and regulations (e.g. heavy regulation of open source models)
- Societal revolt against AI due to job loss, politics, misinformation, and wealth inequality
- Unexpected collapse in scaling laws
- Voluntary or involuntary halt on model advancements due to catastrophic risk
I think there is far greater risk in sitting back and assuming this is all a bubble, than positioning yourself and your company to thrive in the Age of AI.

headline: Co-founder of the AI, Tech & Privacy Academ...
text_content:
🚨 BREAKING: The Future of Life Institute (FLI) 's AI Safety Index Winter 2025 Edition is out! [Bookmark it below] The report’s key findings:
- The top 3 companies from last time, Anthropic, OpenAI, and Google DeepMind, hold their position, with Anthropic receiving the best score in every domain.
- There is a substantial gap between these top three companies and the next tier (xAI, ZAI, Meta, DeepSeek, and Alibaba Cloud), but steps taken by some of these companies show promising signs of improvement that could help close this gap in the next iteration.
- Existential safety remains the sector’s core structural failure, making the widening gap between accelerating AGI/superintelligence efforts and the absence of credible control plans increasingly alarming.
- xAI and Meta have taken meaningful steps towards publishing structured safety frameworks, although limited in scope, measurability, and independent oversight.
- More companies have conducted internal and external evaluations of frontier AI risks, but the risk scope remains narrow, validity is weak, and external reviews are far from independent.
- Although there were no Chinese companies in the Top 3 group, reviewers noted and commended several of their safety practices mandated under domestic regulation.
- Companies’ safety practices are below the bar set by emerging standards, including the EU AI Code of Practice.
*Evidence for the report was collected up until November 8, 2025, and does not reflect the releases of Google DeepMind’s Gemini 3 Pro, xAI’s Grok 4.1, OpenAI’s GPT-5.1, or Anthropic’s Claude Opus 4.5.

name: Marcia Stouse
headline: CEO, CFO, CDO, CMO | Causal AI | Fiduciary Risk Mitigation |...
text_content:
Jon Miller • 1st
Marketo Cofounder | AI Marketing Automation Pioneer | Rein...
Visit my website
6h • 🌐
80% of CEOs don't trust their CMOs (McKinsey). 34% of Fortune 500 companies eliminated the role entirely (Spencer Stuart).
"They just don't understand."
I've been on both sides of this relationship: CMO at Marketo and Engagio, and CEO at Engagio and my current startup. Having sat in both chairs gives me perspective on why this disconnect exists.
THE CMO PERSPECTIVE
You're drowning in tactical work while being asked to do more with less. Marketing budgets fell 15% (Gartner), yet the pressure to drive immediate results keeps intensifying.
Everyone has an opinion about your work. The CEO wants leads. The CFO questions every dollar. Sales complains about lead quality. You're fighting fire drills while trying to build long-term brand equity that takes quarters to show results.
THE CEO PERSPECTIVE
You see massive marketing spend to revenue. When you ask "what's the ROI on this campaign?" you get complex answers about attribution, touches and conversion rates.
It's unclear how all the marketing activity impacts the business. You see a team of 15 people running webinars, writing blogs, and posting on social media — but you can't trace a direct line from that work to closed deals.
Marketing feels like the only department that can't give you straight answers about what's working.
TURNS OUT, BOTH PERSPECTIVES ARE RIGHT
The disconnect results from the fact that the system changed, but our mental models didn't keep up.
Marketing used to work like a gumball machine: budget in, leads out. Everyone understood that model. It was measurable, predictable, linear.
But B2B buying completely changed. With 6–10 people in the buying committee, 70% of the journey happening anonymously, and 80% of buyers choosing vendors before ever talking to sales (6sense), the gumball machine is broken.
Brand, positioning, and market perception now drive revenue more than any single campaign. But these operate on different timelines than the clean attribution CEOs want.
THE PATH FORWARD
CEOs need to understand marketing the same way they understand product development. They don't write code, but grasp how it actually works now. Recognize that the gumball machine model is dead. Product market fit and brand are what creates the conditions that make revenue possible.
CMOs need to speak the language of business outcomes the CEO tracks — pipeline efficiency, CAC trends, competitive win rates, deal velocity — while also educating leadership on why modern B2B buying makes short-term measurement meaningless. The complexity isn't an excuse. It's the reality of how buying committees make decisions across months-long journeys with multiple anonymous touchpoints.
Mutual understanding starts with both sides acknowledging that marketing isn't what it used to be. And that's not anyone's fault.
What's been your experience bridging this gap? Where do you see the biggest misalignment between marketing and the C-suite?

name: Brianna Juul
headline: Rektor hos Slotshaven Gymnasium
text_content:
I dag har jeg givet elleve skriftlige advarsler til 3.g-elever. De er givet på grund af snyd med AI. Det er beklageligt og et udtryk for, at jeg som rektor har brug for mere hjælp end jeg får.
Jeg giver advarslerne for at beskytte en grundlæggende præmis i vores uddannelsessystem: at eleverne lærer ved at arbejde med stoffet selv. Jeg tænker, at hele uddannelsesdanmark er under pres her. Jeg mener også, at vi kun klarer os, hvis der snart kommer udmeldinger og hjælp fra oven, så de flere stjerner på skuldrene end rektorerne rundt om i Danmark.
De elleve advarsler blev givet efter vores mini-SOP-forløb, som er generalprøven på forårets store SOP-projekt.
Eleverne skrev i et sprog, der ikke lignede deres eget, de inddrog imponerende fagbegreber uden forbindelse til pensum, der var ingen kildehenvisninger i opgaverne, men dog litteraturlister, som eleverne ikke kunne redegøre for, når lærerne spurgte dem. De får en tur til toppen af isbjerget.
Det kan siges kort, vi kan ikke længere klare at være overladt til os selv på dette spørgsmål. Det ender med at være et svigt, hvis ikke der kommer hjælp fra centralt hold. Ikke til at fange flere i snyd, men til at skabe klare retningslinjer, som lærerne kan læne sig op ad. Det kræver flere løsninger og mange nuancer om hvorfor de er gode eller ej. Men der er dog løsninger i et landskab, hvor vi gymnasier ikke bliver tilbudt hjælp fra centralt hold. De unges opfattelse af læring er i forandring. Det bliver normaliseret at aflevere produkter, de ikke selv mestrer indholdet af.
Vi har øjeblikkeligt brug for hjælp, hvis vi skal gå i takt og styrke et konstruktivt fagligt miljø og ikke mindst gode relationer til vores elever.
Kort info:
På Slottet rammesætter vi selvfølgelig tydeligt. Alle 1.g-elever har AI-timer som en del af introen. Eleverne hører, at hos os følger vi et mestringsprincip. Det betyder, at eleverne kun må anvende AI-løsninger, når en lærer vurderer, at eleverne mestrer indholdet på et niveau til at kunne verificere indholdet. Vi har efteruddannet vores personale og mange andre ting. Men vi bliver fortsat overhalet af udviklingen fra en generation, der ikke googler, men nu spørger AI-svaret overst oppe i søgningen som sikker viden.

name: Justine Johnson
headline: Cofounder, Why of AI | Growth & GTM Leader...
text_content:
Client called yesterday: "We're canceling our AI transformation."
Best decision they've made.
They'd burned $320K on consultants. Six months of steering committees. Zero actual problems solved.
Their CFO was ready to kill the whole thing. Until we sent one email that flipped his perspective.
The email was simple: "What if you're solving the wrong problem?"
They were building an AI-powered customer insights platform. Meanwhile, their sales team spent 4 hours daily updating CRM fields manually. Their ops team reconciled inventory across 3 systems in Excel. Their customer service reps copy-pasted between 5 different tools.
They were so focused on the sexy AI moonshot, they ignored the bleeding.
73% of AI projects fail because companies chase "transformation" before automation. They want the magazine cover story, not the boring wins that actually matter.
I sent them our dead-simple framework:
KILL THESE PROJECTS:
☐ 6+ month timeline to working solution
☐ Transformation in the project name
☐ No clear owner who feels the pain daily
☐ Success = "AI adoption"
☐ Built by consultants who leave after launch
START THESE INSTEAD:
☑ 2-week sprints to working solution
☑ Fixes a process someone hates right now
☑ Owned by the person it helps most
☑ Success = hours saved this week
☑ Built by your team using existing tools
We killed their $2M customer insights platform. Started with their sales team's CRM nightmare instead.
Two weeks later: 4 hours -> 20 minutes daily. Just using Claude and some basic automation. Cost: $500/month.
Their sales team became instant AI evangelists. Not because we forced adoption. Because we gave them their evenings back.
The CFO who wanted to cancel everything? Now he's asking what other "boring" problems we can fix.
Most AI projects should die before they start. Not because AI doesn't work. Because you're aiming at the wrong target.
Your employees know exactly which processes are killing productivity. They complain about them at lunch. They build janky workarounds in Excel. They're practically screaming the answer at you.
Stop chasing transformation. Start fixing what pisses people off.
What manual process is your team secretly building workarounds for right now?

name: Edith Gandia
headline: AI Trainer for B2B Marketing & Sales Teams...
text_content:
“The output from ChatGPT was terrible. So I just did it myself.”
I’ve heard this from a few marketing pros recently.
And I get it. I’ve been there myself.
Fortunately, the key to getting the most out of these tools isn’t mastering some complex prompt engineering system or saving a bunch of clever-sounding prompts you find online.
It’s simpler than that. It’s about context engineering. Which is a fancy way of saying that you need to give the model the right context to produce the best output.
Think about when you brief a junior team member on a project. You just don't say “write a landing page” and walk away. You tell them who the audience is, what tone to use, what the goal is. You probably share an example of what good looks like.
AI needs the same thing.
So when AI gives you garbage, I’ve found it’s usually because one of three things is missing. I call it the 3R Debugging Trick:
ROLE: Did you tell the model who it's pretending to be? (A conversion copywriter? A brand strategist?)
REFERENCE: Did you give it examples, your brand voice, or context about your company?
REQUIREMENTS: Did you specify structure, audience state, desired outcome?
A vague prompt --> "Write an email to nurture CFO leads for our software."
A contextualized prompt --> "Write a follow-up email to CFOs who downloaded our ROI calculator last week but haven't scheduled a demo. They're overwhelmed by manual reporting right now. Keep it under 150 words, reference the specific pain point they explored in the calculator, and include one customer proof point from the manufacturing sector. CTA should be low-friction: Ask if we can forward them two case studies of customers who were facing a similar situation."
Same tool. Completely different output.
The real skill with AI is learning to provide better context. And the 3R framework gives you a 30-second diagnostic to check if you're doing that.
Next time your AI output falls flat, don't give up and do it yourself. Use this 3R debugging trick first.
You'll be surprised how often that simple check turns a useless output into something you can actually work with.
Have you run into this? What’s been your experience trying to get useful output from AI?

name: Augusta Wick
headline: Global Brand Strategist | B2B Marketing Innov...
text_content:
We were warned in 2015. We ignored it. Now we're paying for it.
Just re-read this brilliant 2015 FT piece (full article in the comments) about advertising’s great plea for respect. And bloody hell, it reads like prophecy.
Ten years ago, whilst everyone was genuflecting before the altar of “digital metrics” and “performance marketing,” Byron Sharp was quietly publishing research showing that brands grow through physical and mental availability. Not loyal fans. That your actual customers are mostly people who buy you once every 18 months and ignore you the rest of the time.
The industry’s response? “Lovely theory, Byron. Now excuse us whilst we spend millions building a TikTok presence for brand love.”
Here’s what makes me want to weep:
Pepsi ditched the Super Bowl in 2010 for a “digital engagement project.” Got millions of likes. Lost 5% market share. That’s not a rounding error—that’s a catastrophe with a hashtag.
Meanwhile, John Lewis created TV ads that made grown adults cry about penguins, and sold so much merchandise they had to apologise for the queue.
We traded effective reach for “engagement.” We traded “mental availability” (being remembered at the point of purchase) for “engagement” (three bot accounts and your mum).
The really depressing bit? Ten years later, we’re still doing it. Still confusing performance marketing with brand building. Still chasing clicks instead of memory structures. Still letting data scientists tell us that emotion is “inefficient.”
You know what’s inefficient? Spending a fortune targeting your “loyalists” whilst your competitor colonises the memories of everyone else.
The fame of a brand takes years to build but becomes, as Buffett understood, “a gusher of cash, cascading down the generations.” But we’d rather have the dopamine hit of Tuesday’s click-through rates.
Perhaps the real lesson: In any industry threatened by technological disruption, the gravest danger isn’t being too slow to adopt the new thing—it’s forgetting what made you valuable in the first place.
Or as I’d put it: we were so busy becoming data scientists, we forgot how to be interesting.

Before the pandemic, at closing time on a typical chilly Wednesday in December like right now...
I'd pack up my laptop, double cheek the train schedule, and start my commute home from a tech PR agency in downtown Boston.
Two hours door to door.
Each way.
God that was demoralizing. 😔
Four hours of daily travel to open my laptop in HQ instead of literally anywhere else with a WIFI connection 💻
In retrospect that seems insane.
All of it.
What a waste of hours better spent playing with my kids or cooking or making healthy meals for my family.
Once you see the folly of it all you can't unsee it 👀
I'm not bashing anyone who prefers commuting to an office.
You do you.
I'm just telling ya'll my mental health is SO much better now.
Working where I want, wearing what I want.
Saving so much money on trains and parking.
Eating much healthier.
Sleeping far better.
Laughing more.
Polluting less.
No, flexible work isn't for everyone.
But for me and my team at Crackle PR ?
This is the way 🤠

name: Michelle Rajs-Garcia
headline: Co-Founder | AI Consultant & Strategist | Crea...
text_content:
Your AI isn't broken. Your instructions are.
Stop expecting ChatGPT (or any other LLM) to be a mind reader.
Prompt engineering is not a technical skill. It is a cognitive skill. It's about management. It's about communication.
Here is the reality we see at Lerns.AI. Most people think "collaboration" means just chatting with the bot.
But collaboration without clarity is just noise.
Think about asking a toddler to clean their room.
If I stand there and say: "Clean this up."
What happens? He panics. He shoves a toy under the rug. He thinks he is done because the floor is visible.
Technically, he "cleaned." Practically, he failed.
Why? Because I didn't define the expectation.
Now, imagine I do this instead:
I sit down with him and say: "Okay, we are going to clean. But here is exactly what that means."
The blocks go in the blue bin.
The books go on the shelf.
The dirty socks go in the hamper.
Suddenly, he wins. And I get the outcome I was looking for.
AI is exactly the same.
If you say: "Write me a blog post about sales." You get a generic, boring wall of text.
If you say: "I need a blog post for exhausted agency owners. The tone should be witty but empathetic. The goal is to make them feel understood, not sold to. Use short sentences."
Now you have a result you can use.
Collaboration isn't just hanging out. It is clearly defining the outcome so the partner can actually succeed.
You don't need to learn code. You need to learn how to explain what is inside your head.
Are you giving your AI a roadmap, or just a destination? 👇

- Ask for specific design feedback with instructions on how to fix it
- Implement its suggestions
- Upload again and repeat until the image is good
Instead of asking it to create stuff for you, must better to create, and ask for feedback.
Bonus points if you have some design inspo and ask how you can make the thing look like your inspo design

name: Alba Gega
headline: CEO @ Alza | Most tech job seekers interview...
text_content:
A guy went viral on LinkedIn this week.
Former Google.
Two years unemployed.
Thousands of people commenting with sympathy, hearts, prayers, resumes, advice, all of it.
I left a comment and said, "Happy to help. Here are a few resumes I loved. If you're happy, I'll chat with you for free."
In a nutshell.
He sent me a connection request.
I accepted.
I said, "Two years is a long time. Curious about your situation and happy to offer any insight that could help."
He said, "No thanks."
I said, "Odd. You reached out to me, so I assumed you actually wanted help."
Blocked.
Let me get this straight:
You are unemployed for two years.
You are publicly begging the entire internet for assistance.
You connect with someone who does this for a living and has generated over 20M in offers, including offers at your former company in 57 days on average.
You reach out to someone who literally helps people get hired every single day.
And your response is...
No thanks, followed by block.
The truth is, a lot of people do not actually want help.
They want attention.
They want sympathy.
They want the dopamine hit of going viral for being stuck.
Because if help actually worked, the excuse disappears and then you are left with responsibility.
Two years unemployed and blocking someone who offered to help.
That is not Bad Luck.
That is not the economy.
That is not "no one will give me a chance."
That is self-sabotage at Olympic level.
Here is the lesson:
If you want to get unstuck, you cannot behave like this guy.
You cannot spit on the opportunity you say you want.
You cannot beg for a lifeline and then cut the rope the moment someone throws it to you.
If you are someone who actually wants to take action
Someone who is not allergic to help,
Someone who is ready to fix their positioning, rebuild their leverage, and stop living inside the comments section of their own pity party...
Message me.
I will help you.
I always do.

name: Nellie Klement
headline: CMO @ Perspective
text_content:
A few days ago, I hit 11k followers. My content strategist said, “That’s a good moment to introduce yourself.” So here's the quick recap.
At 15, I stumbled into freelancing.
No grand vision, just curiosity and the urge to figure things out.
One project led to another.
Before I knew it, I was:
-> Building landing pages
-> Running SEO campaigns
-> Setting up ads for anyone who needed them
By 18, that turned into a LinkedIn Ads agency doing nearly €40k per month.
But the more I scaled, the more I realized I didn't want to keep selling time for money.
(One of the reasons why SaaS had always fascinated me)
I studied every SaaS founder I watched with, learning their playbooks, trying to crack the code of scaling software.
Then I saw a Perspective ad.
The story clicked. An agency-turned-SaaS, scaling fast.
So when Mikey reached out, I had a choice:
❌ Stay in the agency game, making great money but always chasing the next client.
✅ Go all-in on something that could scale beyond me.
Fast-forward a bit.
I sold the agency, joined Perspective as Head of Growth, and never looked back.
Since then, we’ve:
-> Scaled to 8-figures ARR with over 6,000 customers
-> Built a Meta Ads playbook that hat drives predictable growth
-> Started expanding internationally
But what really gets me excited?
-> Figuring out what actually moves the needle (hint: it's usually not what people think)
-> Solving growth problems in a way that’s repeatable, sustainable, and scalable
-> Doing all of that while building alongside my closest friends (that alone is wild)
Can't wait for what's next.
Thanks for tagging along!
Vita maxima 🌟

headline: AI & Emerging Technologies | SaaS Growth Le...
text_content:
Stop making your customers work so hard to give you their money.
New stats show $1.59 BILLION of trade-in value was returned to customers in Q3. That is a 46% increase YoY. 📈
The demand is massive, and it isn't just about a better camera. People are swapping because the software they want to use literally won't run on their current device. This is a hardware supercycle laddering up to the AI supercycle.
Yet, the trade-in experience is notorious for being painful:
• Hunting for your IMEI number
• Grading the condition of your phone
• A mirror selfie to prove screen quality
Every bit of friction isn't just a dropped session; it is a customer walking straight to a competitor who makes it easier to say "Yes."
As a digital telco leader, trade-in is an opportunity to prove you care about loyalty to your customers. It is the single most complex digital transaction a telco customer performs, requiring trust, data input, physical verification, and price acceptance.
Don't let a bad experience be the reason you lose a high-value digital subscriber.

name: Marcia Sheridan
headline: One of the most engaging keynote speakers on...
text_content:
Have you ever given a "perfect" speech? Not a good speech. Not an above-average speech. But the kind where something else enters the room?
I had that experience last year. And even now, it's hard to describe. It felt almost other-worldly...an intensity I'd only felt one or two other times in 13 years of professional speaking - and the impact on my business has been unlike anything I've seen.
But here's what's so fascinating:
It wasn't a keynote.
It wasn't a massive stage.
It was a 90-minute sales class for about 100 boat and marine retailers.
I had taught this same event four different times. Always great. Always productive. But nothing prepared me for what happened that day.
From the moment I started speaking, I could feel something building inside me, as if my desire to help the room was too big to be contained. The energy wasn't normal. It wasn't rehearsed or fake. It was real. Almost physically overwhelming.
And the audience...you could see it in their faces, their posture, their eyes.
People in the conference hall were even crowding around the entrance of the session to watch, as there was clearly something "special" happening and everyone could feel it.
But after the event came the moment I'd never experienced before.
From that room of roughly 100 attendees...
11 different event invitations for 2025 came out of it.
One small audience turned into an entire year of work.
And those 11 speeches?
They've had a major impact on my businesses - far more than I could have ever predicted. Leading to multiple other events and long-term coaching engagements.
But here's the part that keeps me thinking:
I spoke for that same group four other times to that same audience...Why wasn't that magic there?? Why didn't those talks lead to a calendar full of opportunities?
Truthfully? I don't know.
Sometimes life hands you a moment.
Almost like a window.
And you get a surge of connection and clarity you couldn't script if you tried.
As a professional (speaker, salesperson, leader, etc.) you never know when that moment is going to hit. You never know which room, which audience, which seemingly "regular" day will become the door that opens dozens of doors.
Which is why the work matters.
The reps matter.
The showing up matters.
Do the reps.
Keep sharpening the craft.
And when you least expect it...
Lightning strikes.
PS: Today, I'm back at this same event for the Marine Retailers Association of the Americas (MRAA) for the fifth year in a row, and who knows, maybe we'll find lightning in a bottle twice... wish me luck! 😉
[Image/Video Placeholder]

name: Tina El-Sheikh
headline: Serial Deeptech AI Entrepreneur Since 2002 - ...
text_content:
OMG! When will companies learn that using Generative AI as an "alternative" will *always* backfire and damage their brand image? 🤦🏻‍♂️👇
I've said this so many times, free of charge, that GenAI is not a human replacement, nor should it ever replace anything within your organisation — please refer to my previous posts, my articles on Youtube and TikTok, The CEO Retort podcast and newsletter.
As per Futurism 's report, mainstream companies like Coca-Cola and Google are jumping on this bandwagon to plop out new advertisements. There's just one issue: pretty much everybody hates it.
This writing has always been on the wall, lads. Maybe I should be charging for my free advice to make these people listen 🤔
This year, McDonald's decided to get in on the corporate slopfest with a 45-second Christmas spot cooked up for its Netherlands Division by the ad agency TBWA\Neboko. The entire thing is AI, and revolves around the thesis that the holiday season is the "most terrible time of the year," according to the report.
“The ad assaults the viewer with rapidly-changing scenes played out in AI’s typically nauseating fashion, Because most videos generated with AI tend to lose continuity after a handful of seconds, scenes have become extremely quick, becoming one of the key tells that the clip you’re watching is AI.”
And the user comments were brutal 😂
As Futurism put it perfectly, while the contractors behind the video may be proud of their technically impressive work, the public sentiment is clear. If we have to be constantly blasted by commodified sludge, they could at least be made by a human.
I would add that it will be even better if we stop being bombarded by the obnoxious technobros!
OK OK, I know I'm one of them. But I'm doing my best 🥺
Large language models (LLMs) can absolutely enhance many UX designs and ideas — I'm prioritising “Conversational User Interfaces”, for example.
But the idea of using LLMs/GenAI as a replacement for designers, authors, video producers, artists, musicians and the like is simply ridiculous.
As Dr. Jeffrey Funk told me when we discussed the AI bubble this summer (while most people ignored the concept at the time), and as he said directly to me: these people do not understand work! [1]
I mentioned many times that allowing your AI FOMO and, frankly, ignorance about how things actually work, to dictate your AI “strategy” and how you choose to deploy AI will destroy your brand image. We've seen it with Duolingo, Klarna, Spotify, and many others.
This is why I mentioned in early 2024 that Apple, as an example, seem to be the only major company moving in the right direction by NOT jumping on this hype bandwagon. In fact, more recently I discussed why they appear to be abandoning the whole thing altogether [2][3][4]
No wonder Sam Altman came out calling Apple he's main rival 😂 [5]
Be smart with your AI, or your customers will call you a moron (as per the comments to McDonald's ad) 🤷🏻‍♂️
#ceo #ceor #ai #reality

name: Liz Willits
headline: “Liz is the #1 marketer to follow on LinkedIn.”...
text_content:
Talk to anyone who's been consistently successful in marketing and you'll notice something strange.
They're not saying anything new.
You'll hear the same ideas again and again:
⚡️ Know your customer
⚡️ Nail the value prop
⚡️ Be consistent
⚡️ Distribute aggressively
⚡️ Test and iterate
We all know this stuff.
And yet, most marketing still underperforms.
Why?
Ideas are cheap.
Execution is expensive.
And execution doesn't mean "do more."
It means:
⚡️ Doing fewer things well
⚡️ Ruthlessly prioritizing
⚡️ Going deep instead of wide
⚡️ Using good ideas to focus on right ones
⚡️ Saying no to work that looks impressive but doesn't move revenue
Great marketing isn't doing everything.
It's not constant reinvention.
It's:
- disciplined execution.
- good bets.
- relentless follow-through.
- a balance of speed and quality
Ideas are cheap.
Execution — done well — is expensive.
That's why so few people actually do it.

name: Rhonda Tite
headline: Leadership Keynote Speaker | Best-Selling Author | Founder...
text_content:
After all these years, I still hear a voice in my head while I’m presenting. You may hear it, too.
Depending on your level of experience, the voice can range from “You don’t belong on this stage” to “You’re old news.”
In my case, the voice says things like,
“They don’t understand your rationale.” “They don’t think you’re funny.”
And some time, “OMG your zipper is down.”
Here’s some advice: Give the voice a voice.
Say the thing you think they’re thinking.
Call it out. Directly.
“You may think that rationale doesn’t apply to this business. Here’s why it does.”
“That example was stupid and silly. But there is something important we can take from it.”
“Has my zipper been down the whole time? Great.”
When you address the elephant in the room, you take control of the room.
Come on, audiences don’t expect perfection. They expect honesty. Take the wind out of their body language and feedback sails by calling it out before they do.
Don’t try to silence the inner critic. Put it onstage.
Give the voice a voice.

We have tools that could make every interaction more meaningful. Instead, we’re using them to be more careless.
That’s not technology failing us. That’s us failing the technology.
Anyone else seeing AI used to lower the bar instead of raising it?

name: Davina Spinks
headline: founder coach | transition guide | community st...
text_content:
a challenge i have with "no self promo" rules in communities:
it ignores the social capital at play.
for example, i notice i don't like it when someone promotes themselves if they haven't been active in the community. it just feels extractive.
but if someone has been actively involved, helping others, and i know and trust them, i get excited when they promote themselves. i want to know what they're creating and i want to support them.
but because of the first scenario, where folks are more extractive, we create rules that say no one can promote themselves.
as a result we lose the benefits of supporting and being supported in the second scenario.
in an ideal world there would be a more fluid system, where members are invited to promote themselves more as they become more engaged in the community.
perhaps communities can organically navigate this, naming when a member seems to be taking more than giving in a way that's honest, inclusive, and secure.
but that's really fucking hard. for the majority of us, we just have to resort to arbitrary rules.

name: Davina Feinberg
headline: VP, Risk & Insurance at Justworks
text_content:
Justworks was named to Inc. Magazine's 2025 Best in Business list, recognizing companies that achieved breakthrough moments with sizable industry impact.
For Justworks, that impact came through advocacy.
By late 2024, we had nearly 1,000 customers awaiting roughly $145M in legitimate ERTC claims stuck at the IRS. The average customer employed just 12 people and was owed $159,000. Many were making their first layoffs or forgoing growth investments after waiting 18-24 months for funds they rightfully earned.
So we took action. We brought small business owners to Washington D.C. We built a coalition of lawmakers. We fought until the IRS released $50M in March and another $40M in May.
Then, we were one of the first PEOs to ensure that $5.2M in interest-related credits made its way back to the business owners who earned it.
Justworks isn't just an HR platform. We're a relentless advocate. We show up when it's hard. And we believe every dollar of government relief belongs to the small businesses that rightfully claimed it.
Thank you to Inc. Magazine for this recognition, and to every customer who trusted us to fight alongside you.

name: Justine Levy
headline: Director, Social Media & Influencer Marketing,...
text_content:
Most brands talk about influencers.
Very few actually understand how creator programs work.
You should still rely on your owned channels such as brand social, executive and employee advocacy, newsletters, and more because they help with thought leadership, brand awareness, demand gen, search, and AI overview.
They matter.
But there's a limit to how far your owned channels can take you.
Creators take you further.
Here's the simple reason:
Creators reach communities you can't reach naturally. Their audiences trust them, follow them, and act on their recommendations.
And when you partner with them the right way, it shows.
The tactics are specific:
1️⃣ Go where the influence lives.
Focus on platforms like LinkedIn, YouTube and Substack, where creators already have deep trust.
Don't try to drag their audience to your site immediately. Play on their turf.
2️⃣ Ditch the straight demo.
Don't script every word of what they say. You want creators to break down your product in their own way.
Sure, provide them a campaign brief and review their content but give them the creative freedom.
3️⃣ Focus on context.
Show how it integrates into a larger tech stack or demonstrate how it solves a real problem they face with their stack.
It shifts the tone from a sales pitch to a natural recommendation.
It is a creator showing their community how they *actually* work.
This builds trust and presence in a way owned channels never can. Additionally, your owned channels can tap into an ever-growing echo chamber.
I chatted with Finn Thormeier about this and a lot more. Check out the full episode ⤵️
[Image/Video Placeholder]

headline: CEO, CFO, CDO, CMO | Causal AI | Fiduciary Ri...
text_content:
Can we agree that replacing people with machines is not the goal?
And that the "replacement" narrative only appeals to the most short-term oriented, extractive managers and investors?
And that given that logic, replacing the leaders / decision-makers is next?
If you've been reading the Proof Causal.ai / Fiduciari 2025 GTM Effectiveness Report this week, you know that technology hasn't corrected perspective, the right logic, really matters. Technology multiplies and compounds the perspective that we -- People -- give to it. When our logic is flawed, tech makes it even more so.
That's exactly why #GenAI can be such a problem -- it is a stochastic mirror of human tribal knowledge on the internet. There's broad agreement that about 80-90 percent of that knowledge is non-fact. That doesn't mean it's necessary wrong or a lie, but it does mean that it's unproven and essentially an opinion. And because LLMs are reviewing information at a scale and speed that you and I cannot attain ourselves, it exacerbates where we get things wrong.
The goal of a business is to serve its customers and the marketplace with increasing effectiveness, something that give it the basis to charge money for its products or services. Increasing our effectiveness with the full array of AI tools is #causally much more important than using it to replace people and shave costs.
Ayse Guvencer

name: Roberta Jack
headline: Web developer turned growth marketer. Built Tr...
text_content:
Quietly, the best growth marketers I know all did the same thing this year. They stopped hiring.
Not because business is bad. They figured out something the rest of the industry hasn't caught up to yet.
Here's what flipped it for me.
Last month I built a full marketing site plus all the content from scratch. A year ago, I would have hired that out without giving it a second thought. Find a dev, hire a copywriter, manage 3 months of back-and-forth. Instead I knocked it out myself in a weekend, and the final result was superior to what I would have gotten doing it the old way.
That project rewired my brain. What else have I been paying for that I could just handle myself with the help of AI?
Now I say yes to work I would've passed on before. Not because I'm grinding harder. The math just changed. I used to be limited by hours. Now the only limit is what I can think up.
The marketers still building teams and hiring everything out aren't against AI. They just haven't gone deep enough to see what it unlocks. You can't understand it until you've lived it.
If you still believe growth requires headcount, here's my challenge to you: pick your next project and use AI for as much of it as possible. Not as a sidekick. As the one doing the bulk of the work. Let it write the code. Design the ads. Generate the pile. You guide, it executes.
One project will change everything.

text_content:
As open enrollment season ends and Christmas lists are made, it’s a good time to remember: shopping your healthcare matters.

People can't be expected to always understand how their providers are paid or how their plan is funded. But people understand stories.

Talk about the surgeon that costs more on Tuesday than Thursday, that the MRI doesn't need to be done under the same logo as who ordered it.

Tell them the questions you asked the last time you bought a car or a camera. Then explain how to ask your provider the same question (swap miles per gallon with patient outcomes, cost of maintenance with follow up care options).

Our call to action: Tell your story. When your friend, your colleague, your client saves, they'll have their own story to tell.

#employeebenefits #openenrollment #HR #selffunding #pricetransparency #healthcare

Most employers assume their plan design naturally leads employees to high quality and affordable care.

name: Grace Furlong
headline: Chief Strategy Officer | Exp: Google, Mi...
text_content:
Something is broken with this chart.

American households now spend more on Healthcare than Groceries or Housing.

It's baffling. No other advanced economy spends like this.

Two forces are at play here:
-> Cheaper food with poor nutritional benefits
-> Expensive medical approaches with lower efficacy

It's a flywheel of deterioration.

Americans spend more and get less value - shorter life expectancy and lower overall health than peers.

That's not a good equation to be part of.

The average family health insurance plan now costs $27,000 a year - up 6% from last year, following two years of 7% increases. Dramatically outpacing inflation.

With the development of AI some experts predict that medical expertise can essentially go to zero cost, AI will provide free primary care and even advanced diagnostics to everyone, globally. It's a remarkable truth but the establishment has a lot to lose, so it's going to take outside insurgents to shake things up and call in the required change.

Chart Source: New York Times

#healthcare #aihealth #neweconomy #insights [Image]

Healthcare doesn't start in a claims file - it starts upstream.

Before the Rx. Before the ER visit. Before the chronic condition sets in.

They’re trying to navigate symptoms, stress, and everyday life and the system often makes that harder, not easier.

People want access that’s simple.
Care that’s affordable.
Support that actually makes sense in real-world moments - whether that’s urgent care, behavioral health, preventive care, metabolic support, or just getting answers early instead of waiting until things escalate.

As leaders in this industry, we have a responsibility to educate, simplify, and offer options that put people back in control of their health.

And if we want to make an impact in others lives and lower costs, we need to go upstream and meet people where they are.

This is the work that matters.

text_content:
The Ban That Froze Competition

In 2010, the Affordable Care Act placed a moratorium on new physician-owned hospitals.

#POHs face severe growth caps, limiting bed expansion and service line diversification.

Health systems face no such constraints.

Studies consistently show physician-owned hospitals deliver excellent outcomes at lower costs.

How I wish this was about quality and prices and lowering healthcare costs for the American people.

But alas, this is about protecting incumbents from competition.

The same Congress that claims to support "market-based solutions" banned the most market-based solution in healthcare.

text_content:
Weekend thoughts: The childhood vaccine schedule is in serious trouble. It's clear there's a fundamental disconnect between what most clinicians and scientists understand about vaccine mechanisms and safety and what the public understands. Nurses have immense potential to bridge this consequential gap because the public trusts us more than any other profession.

However, nurses are more likely than other clinician types to question vaccine safety and to refuse annual flu shots. I'm not sure if we, collectively are collectively delivering in the pre-licensure curriculum to educate on vaccines, or the immunology and genetics of that education. This is so important now, as students are coming into our programs with at least some exposure to anti-vaccine content.

Nurse Educators & American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN) colleagues, what do you think about the degree and quality of vaccine-related education in RN programs? How could we be doing better?

headline: DNP, ACNP-BC, FAAN, FAANP, FCCP, F...
text_content:
I’m sitting with a lot of frustration today.

Every time something major comes down that affects nursing education it just reminds me how unprepared we are as a profession to respond with one voice.

NURSING IS POLITICAL whether we want to admit it or not.
And honestly… we are not showing up like a profession that knows it.

We’re powerful, but we don’t act like it.
Because we don’t move together.
We get stuck in silos, in titles, in old arguments that don’t get us anywhere.

Meanwhile, decisions about our future get made without us and half the time we don’t even find out until after the fact when it’s too late to stop the wrong fights.

Nursing has a branding issue.
We don’t communicate our power well.
We don’t leverage it when it matters.
And we don’t unify until we’re already backed into a corner.

This latest rule change should’ve been an easy “absolutely not” across the board. No hesitation.

But here we are…

I need us to get it together.
For real.

Can we put agendas down for a minute?
Can we stop acting like we’re on different teams?
Can we show up for this profession like it actually deserves?

This is why Nurses Shift Change exists because so many are advocating for nursing to choose, and don’t understand the urgency of our future shaped by people who don’t understand what we do, don’t value what we know, and don’t include us in decisions that impact millions of lives.

Dr. Michelle A. Nelson always says, “What if we all rallied behind ONE thing?”
I’m starting to think that’s the only way forward.

The power we have. We really do.
We just have to decide collectively to use it.

#NursesShiftChange #Nursing #Leadership #WeAreNursing #Policy

name: Susan Quinn, FNP-C
headline: Director of Health and Counseling Services...
text_content:
The Department of Education's decision to remove Nursing from the list of recognized professional degrees is deeply concerning, and the consequences will be far-reaching.

Nursing is not simply a "graduate degree." It is a licensed, regulated profession requiring advanced clinical judgment, advanced training, and direct responsibility for human lives.

To suggest that Nursing is not a professional field:

👈 Undermines the rigor of graduate-level nursing education
👈 Devalues the critical role of advanced practice roles such as Nurse Practitioners, Nurse Anesthetists, Nurse Midwives, and Clinical Nurse Specialists
👈 Creates confusion for employers, accrediting bodies, and licensing boards
👈 Threatens the recruitment and retention of future nurse leaders
👈 Risks limiting federal support, funding pathways, and recognition for advanced nursing programs
👈 Minimizes the role nurses play as primary care providers, mental health clinicians, and frontline responders

In a time when we are already facing a nursing workforce shortage in healthcare, the answer should never be to devalue the very professionals keeping our systems afloat.

The work nurses do is professional. The education we pursue is professional. The standards we uphold are professional.

Removing Nursing from this classification is not only inaccurate, it is dangerous.

I urge policymakers, educators, healthcare leaders, and professional organizations to push back swiftly and decisively. Our patients, our communities, and our healthcare infrastructure depend on it.

Nurses deserve recognition not just for what we do, but for who we are: Highly trained, highly skilled, indispensable professionals.

name: Dr. Lorre Laws
headline: Author of Nursing Our Healer's Heart, K...
text_content:
☕ Issue 75 Just Dropped 👀

I watched my grandfather rage at a potato chip bag yesterday.

Couldn't get it open. 83 years of unprocessed trauma discharged at an inanimate object.

My daughter - a nurse - watched him erupt. Again.

She asked me later: "Why does he do that?"

Here's what I told her:

Ed was 3 when his mother was paralyzed by polio and his alcoholic father abandoned them. His nervous system never recovered. It stayed in perpetual threat detection mode.

He passed that to my mother. She passed it to me. I passed it to my daughter.

Not through words. Through cells. Through mirror neurons. Through epigenetics.

Four generations of women carrying an 83-year-old wound in our nervous system and mitochondria.

And here's the part that should terrify healthcare leadership:

Megan became a nurse.

She can't handle conflict. Can't set boundaries. Can't tolerate disappointment in others. Makes herself small. Apologizes for existing.

Not because she's weak.

Because her great-grandfather's abandonment lives in her nervous system.

And nursing FEEDS on this.

Systems WANT nurses who:
-> Make themselves small
-> Avoid conflict
-> Never push back
-> Sacrifice endlessly

Three weeks ago, a pharmacy error nearly killed Megan's patient. Not her fault. System failure.

But she CAN'T sleep. She replays it endlessly. She worries about her license.

Because the system doesn't carry trauma. Nurses do.

This is second-victim trauma layered on historical trauma layered on developmental trauma layered on generational trauma.

Two centuries later, you're likely STILL reenacting the traumas of your nurse predecessors. As was I.

You think it's dedication.

It's inherited oppression.

I've analyzed over 1,000 nurses through my 2025 Trauma Assessment.

Their individual trauma scores are significantly higher than any other category.

Your "people-pleasing" isn't a personality trait.
Your "work ethic" isn't admirable.
Your "inability to say no" isn't a character flaw.

They're adaptive trauma responses that healthcare systems exploit for profit.

And your "self-care" won't fix it.

Because the problem isn't individual. It's systemic.

And it's been transmitted through generations of nurses exactly like Ed transmitted trauma to Megan.

76% of burnout symptoms are actually trauma responses.

You're not burning out. You're being traumatized. Daily. Systematically. By design.

Your body never lied to you.
The system did.

Drop a 💔 in the comments if you recognize this pattern in yourself or your team.

And if you're a nurse ready to break this cycle, I've opened 47 spots in my Nurse Relief Starter at $47 (ends Dec 31). Link in bio.

name: Christina Armour
headline: Director of Software Engineering at Gra...
text_content:
We are facing a dangerous paradox in workforce development.

While demand for high-level Cybersecurity professionals and Advanced Practice Nurses is skyrocketing, new federal policy is about to make training them significantly harder.

This isn't just policy to me. It's personal.

As a cybersecurity professional currently managing roughly $60K in student loans, I follow these changes closely. But the alarm bells are ringing even louder for my friends and family in Nursing. Many of them, especially those serving on the front lines of patient care, carry debt loads exceeding $110K just to hold the advanced degrees their jobs require.

Under the newly implemented OBBBA, both of our fields have been reclassified. Degrees in Nursing, Cybersecurity, and Architecture are no longer considered “Professional” for student loan purposes.

The Result? A strict $100K lifetime aggregate cap on federal loans.

Why this is a crisis:

🔻 The Nursing Math Doesn’t Work: My friends in advanced nursing programs (MSN/DNP) are already exceeding the $100K cap. This cap effectively prices out the nurse educators needed to solve the national nursing shortage.

🔻 The Cyber Paradox: The government is funding entry-level skills via Workforce Pell Grants, but simultaneously cutting off the funding for the highly skilled architects and strategists needed to lead the industry.

We are risking a future where advanced degrees in these vital fields are accessible only to the wealthy, not the capable.

Does this new cap impact your career plans?

Read my full breakdown of the OBBBA changes and the immediate impact on our workforce here:

name: Lucy Adams
headline: No buzzwords. 16 years as a bedside cr...
text_content:
Something has been becoming more and more clear to me as I read the news recently.

In most industries, "customer service" is a bonus.

In nursing, it's expected.

In almost every other line of work, people are forgiven for being short-staffed, overwhelmed, behind schedule, or having "an off day."

But in healthcare?

We're expected to be calm while everything is on fire.
We're expected to be compassionate when we're running on fumes.
We're expected to deliver flawless service while carrying workloads that would break most teams in other industries.

And the wild part?

We do it anyway. Every single day.

I used to compare our expectations to what I saw in other places — restaurants, retail, airlines, hotels, customer service lines.

When those industries fall short, people shrug and say, "It is what it is."
We accept it.

When healthcare falls short, it's a headline or a lawsuit.

That used to frustrate me.

But somewhere along the way, I shifted my perspective.

Instead of being frustrated, I've chosen to be proud.

Proud that nurses can do what most industries seemingly can't, rise to the moment even when the moment is brutal.

Proud that our standard of humanity and service hasn't crumbled in a world where customer service is disappearing everywhere else.

Proud that, despite the workload, the pressure, and the emotional toll, nurses still show up for people in their most vulnerable moments with skill, grace, and heart.

Nursing is demanding — inordinately so.

But it's also one of the last professions where integrity, compassion, and real service are still alive. And that's something in which I will always derive pride.
