text_content:
Nursing, Loans, and the DOE: Separating Facts from Fear and Why Your Voice Matters Now

You may have seen the headline that the Department of Education has “ruled nursing is not a professional degree.”

For many nurses, that felt like a gut punch. I see some people panicking and others dismissing it, but the truth is more nuanced and still deeply important for APRNs, nurse educators, and students.

In this new edition of my Nurse Educator Wellness Reset newsletter, I break down:

- What the DOE’s “professional degree” change actually does (and doesn’t) mean
- How new loan caps and the loss of Grad PLUS could impact APRN and graduate nursing programs
- Why nursing organizations like AACN are sounding the alarm

My goal with this piece is simple: mobilize, not terrorize.

Headlines are designed to incite panic, but fear-based headlines don't help. We need facts, and we also deserve a seat at the table while these changes are still taking shape.

I'm curious: How do you think these loan changes could impact your work, or the nurses and students you work with?

👉 If you’re a nurse, nurse educator, APRN, or student, I’d love for you to read this one, share it with your colleagues, and add your perspective.

👉 If you’re in a position to influence policy or education, your voice is especially needed right now.

Together, we can separate facts from fear and use our collective voice to protect the future of advanced nursing practice. 💜

name: Donna Thornton
headline: Sparking the Unhustled Side Hustle Mo...
text_content:
You don’t walk away from teaching because you’re anti-education.
...more
You walk away because you care too much to keep giving from an empty tank.

Most teachers aren’t “quitting.”
They’re trying to protect the part of them that made them great teachers in the first place.

And here’s the hard truth.
You can love your students with your whole heart and still realize the current conditions make it almost impossible to show up as the teacher you want to be.

The workload.
The constant demands.
The never-ending pressure to do more with less.
The paycheck that doesn’t reflect the impact.
The exhaustion that follows you home.

Even the teachers who never cared about the money are saying, “I can’t live like this anymore.”

Not because they stopped caring.
But because caring has become unsustainable.

Wanting something different doesn’t make you less committed to kids.

It means you’re human.
It means you’ve been carrying more than any person should.
It means you see the gap between what students deserve and what the system allows you to give.

You deserve space to breathe.
You deserve options.
You deserve income that doesn’t demand your health, your evenings, or your joy.

If you’re still devoted to teaching but no longer willing to lose yourself in it, you’re not alone.

There are flexible, teacher-friendly ways to create online income that lighten your load rather than add to it.

You can build a future that supports you, so you can keep showing up for others in a way that feels healthy and sustainable.

#teachers #teacherburnout #education #teachertransition #teacherwellbeing #teacherlife #thecfoteacher

name: Lucy Shepard
headline: Discovering the Future of AI in education
text_content:
I want to interview teachers who are using AI in their classrooms. What tools are you using? What’s working well? How are you handling students who use ChatGPT at
...more
home for assignments? And what do you think the next year or two will bring?

Teachers- I’m offering $50 gift cards for a quick discussion of AI use! Sign up here: https://lnkd.in/gRvSVd2R

In May, I started The AI Who Taught Me. I’ve covered research papers, products like School AI and Brisk Teaching, and major offerings from OpenAI and Google. There is plenty of coverage of how kids cheat with ChatGPT and other tools - but there’s not that much coverage about how teachers are actually using AI in mainstream public schools.

It’s not for lack of use. A recent report from CDT offers fascinating, conflicting data:
- Large majority (85%) of teachers have used AI in their classrooms
- The majority of special education teachers are using AI to help with IEPs
- The most common use cases are lesson planning, student engagement, grading, and targeted student support
- YET, a majority of parents believe that “a teacher who uses AI is not really doing their job.”

I want to get past the summary stats and dig in to the details of how AI tools are being used in classrooms. I’ll be working on a long form article to report what I find.

If you are a teacher, please sign up to chat! And share their stories of AI use in the classroom. Please share!

#AlinEducation #EdTech #K12 #Teachers #AI #TheAlWhoTaughtMe

name: Eva Pressman
headline: LinkedIn Top Resume Writer For Transiti...
text_content:
People on television keep hypothesizing what will be the leading downfall of this country over the next 15 years. I can tell you what it will be, and my community knows it...
...more
#TeacherShortage

99% of adults have no idea the world a #Teacher is in and the amount of anxiety, unrealistic expectations, and pressure #Educators must endure. That whole "summers off" thing? fine when your whole job isn't required to keep society afloat, but it is obvious Teachers from brand new to veterans want OUT of the business.

It doesn't matter who it is, but parents, #Administration, and just #School in general try to keep teachers beaten down and quiet, and warn them of the corporate world. "Oh you may not like it, then you have to come back", or, "You know they are going to treat you like a number, here you are part of a family".

Let me tell everyone what is NOT NORMAL
#TransitioningTeacher folks:

1) Getting SHOT at your place of work
2) Getting THREATENED at your place of work
3) Working on your lunch/planning time
4) Being observed by the GOVERNMENT at your job.
5) Being BLAMED for everything.

Let me tell you one thing #Teachers; IT IS OKAY TO PUT YOUR FAMILY FIRST FOR ONCE. From age 18 - Present MOST of you have put EVERYONE else first... your students and everyone else, but guess what; YOU DON'T HAVE TO.

It is NOT YOUR JOB to sacrifice time and energy you could be spending with YOUR KIDS, YOUR SPOUSE, and YOUR LIFE. You have already done 99% more than anyone else in this country and for your community, if you want to quit TERRIBLE conditions you can.

We do not shame people who leave toxic work environments; UNLESS you are an educator. NOT ME, NOT THIS community; you have one life - do not let it be being ruined daily because of what others tell you.

It is okay, to put your family first for once, and look at other options.

If you need help with your transition, your resume writing, or portfolio design, I am here to help. Happy Monday!
[Image of illustration showing a stressed person with text: "WHAT TEACHERS DEAL WITH... IS NOT NORMAL"]

name: Kelly Wheeler
headline: Instructional Designer | Podcaster | Me...
text_content:
It’s frightening how many students enter school and graduate lacking basic reading and writing skills now.
...more
We’re talking about simple things like knowing the alphabet, counting to ten, or recognizing colors in Kindergarten.

Without those basics, educators are forced to spend valuable instruction time catching students up instead of moving them forward. And by the time they reach middle or high school, single subject matter teachers simply aren’t equipped - or given the time - to go back and reteach those early skills.

The result?
⚠️ Social promotion even when they haven’t shown needed competencies.
⚠️ High school seniors graduating without proficiency in reading or math.
⚠️ Burned-out teachers blamed for a system that sets them (and their students) up for failure.

Parents must play a stronger role in preparing children before they ever enter school, because teachers cannot do it all.
Without this foundation, we create a domino effect that hurts students for life and drives more educators out of the profession.

Watch the video here: https://lnkd.in/gkXQZqSQ

name: Marci Brodock
headline: Teacher Leader & Future Administrator |...
text_content:
Teachers are overwhelmed — and with good reason.
The noise, the mandates, the constant pivots... none of that is imagined.
...more
But here's something I've been reflecting on lately:
Not all of the weight we carry comes from the system.
Some of it comes from the battles we keep fighting in our own minds.

We can't control:
"shifting directives"
"new pacing"
"urgency gaps"
"what's urgent this week"

But we can control the part that happens inside the classroom:
understanding our students
responding instead of reacting
professional judgment
choosing to collaborate
our own mindset
our posture toward growth

Teaching has never been simple.
But some of our power returns the moment we shift from "I can't believe they..." to
"What can I influence right now?"

Not as compliance.
Not as surrender.
But as leadership.

Because that's what teachers are — even when the system forgets to treat us like it.

The noise may not stop tomorrow.
But the way we meet it?
That can change everything.

AI in Music: Collaboration, Copyright, and the Search for a Digital Soul

As artificial intelligence continues to transform the world of music creation, three critical questions arise:

-Can AI be considered a true collaborator in the creative process?
-Who owns the music created with AI assistance?
-Does AI possess the creative spark (or even a "soul") to generate meaningful art?

In my latest article, I explore these questions and share my perspective on how AI is reshaping the music industry. From tools that enhance compositions to full AI-generated creations, the implications for ownership and creativity are vast.

Check out the article to dive into the conversation about AI's role in music and its ethical considerations:

I'd love to hear your thoughts, do you think AI can truly create music, or is it merely an enhancer? Let's discuss!

name: Dara Choy
headline: Co-Founder & CPO at Aktana | Pioneeri...
text_content:
This might surprise people who know me through enterprise AI or life sciences, but one of the topics I’ve spent the most time researching this year is…music.

Twenty years ago, music was my passion, something I loved but never imagined would shape my work or parenting. Somewhere between scaling companies, building AI systems, and raising a family that passion faded into the background.

This year, it was unexpectedly reignited.

Not because I suddenly became a musician (I didn’t). But because I rediscovered music at a moment when attention, emotional regulation, and social connection are becoming even harder for kids to develop.

I learned that:
- Music activates more of the brain than almost any other stimulus. Language, motor control, memory, emotion, executive function all light up.
- Kids ages 3 to 8 learn faster and retain longer through melody than spoken instruction.
- Predictable rhythm strengthens communication pathways for neurodivergent learners.
- Musical engagement improves attention, reduces anxiety, and supports emotional regulation, in both children and adults.

There’s a reason people pray through song. A reason nostalgia hits hardest when tied to melody. A reason certain songs help us focus when nothing else does.

As someone who has spent my career thinking about cognitive load, behavioral science, and decision support for humans at work, it’s humbling to see how a simple melody can unlock what sophisticated tools often struggle with.

In many ways music is an underrated technology, one of the oldest we’ve ever had, and maybe still one of the most powerful. Long before we talked about “human-centered design,” communities were using rhythm and story to teach, heal, and pass down knowledge.

#Music #LearningScience #MentalHealth #Neurodiversity #AIProductBuilder #HumanCenteredAI

headline: Cybersecurity Researcher | Applying Se...
text_content:
📚🧠 Learning Cybersecurity Through Music (...yes, really)

Over the past few months, I started doing something unexpected to level up my cybersecurity skills:

✨ I turned my study notes into SONGS. ✨

🎵 I write lyrics to memorize complex concepts.
🎵 I use AI music tools to turn those lyrics into full tracks.

And honestly? It works way better than I ever imagined.

When you’re trying to learn networks, threat intel, acronyms, topologies, protocols...
... music turns all that mental friction into rhythm.

It forces you to:
🔁 Translate concepts into your own words
🔁 Repeat the hardest material again and again
🔁 Recall information automatically when the melody plays
⚡ Stay creative instead of overwhelmed

Two of the biggest hacks I’ve discovered:

👉 #1 Put the most difficult technical content in your CHORUS.
Why?
Because the chorus repeats multiple times every listen. You’re literally drilling the hardest information into long-term memory without even trying. 🤯
(It also reprograms your inner monologue in the best way.)

👉 #2 Try to write the lyrics as much as you can and only use AI to revise rhyming preserving the understanding of the concept in your own words as much as possible.
I noticed that the retention of lyrics was significantly higher when I put in the work to write as much as I could on my own.

Here’s an example from one of my pieces, “Topology”:
(Lyrics in video)

Mixing creativity + cybersecurity might sound unconventional, but in the age of AI-generated music, it's becoming a seriously powerful learning tool.

If you’re studying cybersecurity, cloud, networking, AI, or literally anything technical — try it. You might be shocked how well it sticks.

name: Binyu You
headline: M.S. in Digital Social Media @USC Anne...
text_content:
Microsoft once had a music service that briefly had more paid subscribers than Spotify—and still failed. Why? 🧐

This semester, my team and I completed a deep-dive case study on The Rise and Fall of Microsoft's Xbox/Groove Music.

What started as a research assignment quickly became one of the most interesting product projects I've worked on. We explored the full lifecycle of Microsoft's music ecosystem, from the Zune era to Xbox Music, to Groove's eventual migration to Spotify.

Along the way, we analyzed:
📉 The strategic decisions behind Microsoft's entry into digital music
💸 Why music streaming is structurally unprofitable for tech giants like Microsoft
📱 How cross-device priorities (especially Windows 8 UX) derailed user adoption
🕰️ The major impact of late investment in iOS and Android apps

One of the highlights of this project was speaking with former Microsoft leaders who worked directly on the product. Their perspectives helped us understand not just what happened, but why it happened, especially around licensing economics, internal alignment, and the strategic timing of key decisions.

We boiled down our research into three key lessons for me as a marketer:

1. Audience & Platform Fit
Just because an ecosystem exists doesn’t mean it shows up where the users are. Even strong ideas fail when they’re confined to the wrong hardware.

2. Positioning & Business Reality
Brand, partnerships, and pricing only work when they align with user behavior. Marketing messaging has to reflect how the business truly makes or loses money.

3. Timing & Ecosystem Strategy
In fast-moving consumer categories, timing is often the difference between leading the market and missing it entirely.

I'm incredibly proud of this deck and grateful to everyone who helped us along the way!

Huge thanks to our professor, Adam Fratto, for pushing us to connect storytelling with strategy, and to my teammate Xuanxu Lu for her incredible visual input and teamwork on this case study. I am especially thankful for the industry professionals who generously shared insider insight—their perspective added depth far beyond public sources.

If you're working on entertainment, platforms, or media strategy, I'd love to connect and chat. Always excited to learn from others who are thinking about timing, ecosystems, and audience behavior.

❓Question for the community: Looking at today's market, what is the biggest lesson from the Xbox Music story that modern streaming services should still be paying attention to?

#streaming #music #research #xboxmusic #groovemusic #casestudy #microsoft #GrooveMusic #CaseStudy #TechHistory #MarketingStrategy #Techmarketing [video]

name: Andie Lykens, MBA
headline: Strategic Global Leader & Innovator in...
text_content:
“Don't worry, we can get a deal on the #music. I know the drummer.” 🥁

In my 20 years working on music in #marketing, one of the most persistent tropes from well-meaning creatives is that personal relationships will solve every music problem.

I call this “I know the drummer” syndrome.

Here’s how it usually goes: someone on the team thinks their connection to an artist will unlock a sweetheart deal. Relationships matter, absolutely - but let’s not overlook the complexity of music rights, especially for marketing. 🤝

Music ownership is complicated. The drummer might love your idea, but she probably doesn't control the master recording, the entire composition or potentially even her own likeness rights.

EVEN IF your drummer friend controls everything, you still need to make this call: "I know you make music for a living, but would you discount your work for our six-figure marketing campaign?" 📉

Consider the alternative: position your brand as a valued, repeat music partner. Pay fair fees. Build real relationships across labels, publishers, and artists. Create opportunities that thrill both your target audience and the artist's audience.

What's better – asking your friend for a discount while hoping they own all the rights, or building stunning brand creative that artists actually want to work with?

name: Shauna C.
headline: Photographer | Writer | Progressive Entr...
text_content:
Imagine discovering that our world isn't built despite poverty, but on top of it.
"A World Without Poverty Is The World Our Institutions Fear Most" is a thought experiment that asks a simple question. What happens to religion, government, capitalism, philanthropy, the justice system, and the self-help industry if nobody is poor?
Short answer? They all start to look very differentand far less innocent.
Poverty isn't just "unfortunate." It's a load-bearing feature of the current order:
It gives government a permanent crisis to "manage."
It supplies capitalism with a reserve army of desperate workers.
It furnishes religion and philanthropy with endless moral theatre.
It keeps the justice system's cages full and the self-help industry's customers coming back.
Without poverty, the alibis vanish. The masks come off. We'd be forced to admit how much of our prosperity depends on someone else's precarity.
Read the full piece below:
#Poverty #Inequality #Capitalism #PublicPolicy #Justice #Essay #LongRead

In my moment back, I break down why we need to distinguish the floor (short-term stability) from the ladder (long-term mobility), and why quality jobs must mean predictable hours, benefits that actually reduce risk, and shared ownershipnot just higher pay.
I'd love to hear from you: where are you seeing the gap between what the data says and what it actually takes for people in your community to feel stable and hopeful about the future?

text_content:
What is one of the -- if not 'the' -- most powerful tool to reduce #poverty?
In one word: #redistribution.
Wait... is this true everywhere?
Not at all: In low and middle income countries, the average 'net' effect of taxes-and-transfers is either neutral or even *increases* poverty.
Why? Because the poorest pay more in taxes (esp indirect taxes) to the state than they receive in benefits.
Bottom line: the best-designed #cashtransfer or #socialinsurance or wider #socialprotetcion system may do little if #taxation and wider #fiscalpolicy are not considered!

While most people were winding down their weekend...a mother is trying to figure out how to pay $80 for another night in an extended stay.
Not drugs.
Not laziness.
Not excuses.
Just poverty priced at full retail.
I wrote about something we don't talk about enough  why homelessness isn't what we think it is.
The real face of homelessness is the family sleeping in their SUV,
the woman staying with her abuser because the rent is $600 more than last month, and the father paying triple the price for a week in a motel because poverty charges interest.

For countries aiming to reduce inequality, granular #poverty maps provide the evidence needed to direct resources where they matter most.
#Paraguay has unveiled a detailed monetary poverty map at the district and neighborhood levels, covering all 263 districts and 67 neighborhoods of Asuncin. The data show that, alongside a reduction of more than 30 percentage points in national poverty rates between 2003 and 2024, important regional differences remain.
In districts such as Alto Paraguay and San Pedro, nearly one in two residents still live in monetary poverty, while in parts of Central and the capital the rate is below one in ten.
Review this new Monetary Poverty Map released by the National Statistics Institute (Instituto Nacional de Estadstica (INE) - Paraguay), built collaboratively with the technical support of The World Bank, showcasing how improved poverty visualization can guide more effective policies: lnkd.in/et5Tr7FR

name: Ayana (Sam) A.
headline: Global AI & DeepTech Pioneer | Founder...
text_content:
After 70+ countries and decades in development work through social enterprise, I need to say something uncomfortable:
The patient capital movement is failing.
Not struggling. Failing!
After 50 years of impact investing and social entrepreneurship, poverty has INCREASED in Africa where poor people need the most help and the progress globally is inconsistent everywhere except Scandinavia and China.
Yet we keep saying: "Markets will solve poverty."
I believed this. I was wrong.
Here's what I've learned:
--> Markets help the vulnerable poor (those with some capital)
--> Markets CANNOT reach the truly poor i.e. those in extreme poverty (locked out by oppression)
The deepest poverty isn't a market problem.
It's cultural subjugation + economic exploitation.
In India: caste & gender create an underclass
In US: racial redlining and class construct barriers
In Africa/Arab nations: ethnic, gender & religious hierarchies determine opportunity
Microfinance can't overcome caste discrimination.
Social enterprise can't dismantle racial and gender barriers.
Patient capital can't break ethnic oppression.
These need human solutions, not market solutions.
The uncomfortable truth:
Only two places reduced poverty consistently by combining:
Market discipline
+ massive state redistribution
Not markets alone. Not state control alone. Both.
Yet the industry refuses this conversation.
Instead:
Books use African children on covers (did they get royalties?)
Western "saviors" get welcomed (without reflecting on WHY)
Entrepreneurship stories only help those already positioned to benefit
I wrote about this after reading The Blue Sweater by Jacqueline Novogratz
Valuable lessons on moral imagination and distributed leadership.
But it exposes blind spots that cost us 50 years of progress.
My challenge to the industry:
Stop solving market failures.
Start dismantling oppression.
Not market access by cultural barriers broken, not just businesses created.
Acknowledge your privilege is part of the dynamic.
Center voices of those experiencing poverty.
The question isn't: "How can markets solve poverty?"
The question is: "How do we dismantle systems that create an underclass?"
Read my full breakdown (link in comments).
What's your experience? Seen approaches that address systemic oppression vs just market failures?
Let's have the conversation the industry isn't having.
#Development #SocialImpact #Poverty #SystemicChange #Leadership #SocialEntrepreneurship #PatientCapital #ImpactInvesting

name: Jennifer Frick
headline: I am not telling you something to sell you something. I...
text_content:
The U.S. poverty line is calculated as three times the cost of a minimum food diet in 1963, adjusted for inflation.
I read it again. Three times the minimum food budget. I felt sick. - Michael Green
For 1963, that floor made sense. Housing was relatively cheap. A family could rent a decent apartment or buy a home on a single income. Healthcare was provided by employers and cost relatively little. Childcare didn't really exist as a market, mothers stayed home, family helped, or neighbors watched each other's kids. Cars were affordable. Few frills, College could be covered with a summer job. Retirement meant a pension income, not a 401(k) you had to fund - Michael Green
But everything changed between 1963 and 2024.
Housing costs exploded. Healthcare became the largest household expense for many families. Childcare became a market, and expensive. College went from affordable to crippling. Transportation costs rose. .... The composition of household spending transformed completely. If you keep Orshansky's logic, if you maintain her principle that poverty could be defined by the inverse of food's budget share, but adjust the multiplier to reflect today's reality, the multiplier is no longer three. It becomes sixteen. - Michael Green
Ouch.
Everything's more, and working to cover just ads more costs. Feels a bit Arkansas Chicken farmer.
Great find Katie. Thanks for the intro Chris. Scary post Michael.
Full length post - Part 1: My Life Is a Lie by Michael Green How a Broken Benchmark Quietly Broke America https://lnkd.in/gTwyjpyG
#poverty #americandream #wealth #gettingahead #food #snap #inflation #costs

name: Marla Swiger
headline: Strategic Program Director | Experie...
text_content:
Just read Matt Watkins's "Food Insecurity' and Other Words That Sanitize Poverty" in The Chronicle of Philanthropy and, honestly, it called me out in the best way.
I've leaned on phrases like "food insecurity" and "lack of economic mobility" for years. They sound careful and professionalbut as Matt points out, they can turn hunger and poverty into something abstract and distant, instead of a mother skipping meals so her kids can eat or a senior choosing between rent and medicine.
In my earlier work with Energy Express, we talked about "food deserts" and "literacy deserts" to connect empty pantries and empty bookshelves in kids' lives. That framing helped, but this piece is a good reminder that even when we use accepted terms, we can lose sight of the real human stories underneath them.
Through Pangaea Strategies, my work now focuses on bringing community members, nonprofits, and funders to the same table. Its a daily challenge to remember that the way we talk about those needs shapes whether people feel seen or erased. I cant stop using the language in grants and reports, but that cant become an excuse to sand down the edges of the room with funders, nonprofits, companies, and communities.
If our work is about dignity and fairness, then our language has to reflect the messiness of peoples lives, not blur it. Im going to be much more intentional about saying hunger when I mean hunger, and poverty when I mean need.
Highly recommend this piece for anyone in philanthropy, nonprofits, or policy work. It's definitely made me more focused on my own languageespecially when we're truly faced with real urgency and need.
#Nonprofits #Poverty #Hunger #FoodInsecurity #LanguageMatters #CommunityDevelopment

#PraiseGod
 The Weight of Inequality:
Why "Fancy" Weight Loss Drugs Miss the Rural Poor
The buzz around the new generation of weight-loss drugs is undeniable. But as we celebrate these medical marvels, we must confront a stark reality: for the majority of poor people in rural America, these treatments are nothing more than a fantasy.
The costoften exceeding $1,000 a month without comprehensive insuranceis a luxury the rural poor simply cannot afford. This isn't just about weight; it's about a deep-seated issue of health equity and the social determinants of health.
As White River Now reports on initiatives to boost rural health access, we need to connect the dots...
 Poverty & Isolation:
High poverty rates, fewer job opportunities, and lack of affordable, healthy food options (food deserts) are rampant in rural areas.
 The Vicious Cycle:
Being in a place with limited resources, opportunities, and support can lead to crippling stress and depression. And honestly, if that was you, you would eat too. Food often becomes one of the few accessible comforts in a life defined by struggle.
 Stigma and Scarcity:
To tout these expensive, life-changing drugs without addressing the financial barriers to access only reinforces the cruel "dog-eat-dog" nature of a health system that leaves the most vulnerable with nothing.
A true health revolution means affordable, accessible care for everyone, regardless of their zip code or income.
It cannot be a "breakthrough" that is only available to the wealthy and insured. The conversation must shift from simply treating symptoms to addressing the root causes: poverty, lack of infrastructure, and access to basic human needs.

name: Brenda L.
headline: Community Catalyst | Disruptive Innovator | Servant Le...
text_content:
The silence of this doorway is haunting.
I am visiting Cape Coast, Ghana. We took time to visit the Cape Coast Castle to understand better the history of the country in which we are serving. I found myself lost in thoughts as I stood staring out of the "Gate of No Return."
For countless men and women, this view was the last glimpse of home before they were thrust into the belly of a slave ship to cross the Atlantic. The cries of their hearts deafened my soul as I stood before this gate.
I came to a heavy realization: The gate is old, but the enemy is still active.
It is often easy for us to view slavery as a relic of history. We think that the chains are gone. But today, millions of people still live in modern slavery. The mechanics have changed, but the root driver remains the same: Poverty.
Poverty is a brutal master. It takes advantage of a vulnerability so deep that it strips away dignity. It forces desperate choices. It shoves people to hand over their lives to systems of exploitation, often masked as opportunity.
Poverty tells a child they have no value. It creates spiritual chains of hopelessness that bind our hearts just like iron on the wrists.
This is why I am so passionate about the work we do at Compassion International.
Our goal is not to provide "charity." It is warfare against the chains of poverty. By releasing children from poverty in Jesus name, we are destroying the very foundation that allows slavery and bondage to thrive. We are fighting for spiritual and physical freedom with real hope for the next generation.
Compassion International offers a different gate. It's the one Jesus spoke of when He said, "I am the door" (John 10:9). The gate we are leading people through leads to freedom, not slavery.

text_content:
Hey, everyone. I've been deep in the data on SNAP (what we all know as food stamps), and I wanted to share what I found in my new newsletter.
I started with a simple question: which states are most "dependent" on this help?
But what I found was eye-opening. The gap between states like Massachusetts and Rhode Island vs. states like Wyoming and New Mexico was HUGE.
The economic reliance in New Mexico and D.C. is more than four times higher than in Wyoming.
But the why is the real story. It's not just unemployment. I found a "working poor" paradox: states like Massachusetts and New Mexico have low unemployment but are still in the top 5 for dependency. People are working, but the jobs just don't pay enough to make ends meet.
The most important takeaway for me was who we're really talking about. When you strip away the politics, 70% of all SNAP recipients are kids, seniors, or people with disabilities.
This reliance creates a serious vulnerability. A federal shutdown isn't a "news story" in a high-dependency state; it's a direct threat to the food security of one in every five people.
I wrote about all of it in a conversational, folksy style, just like this. You can read the full newsletter here.

text_content:
Why is LinkedIn now limiting how many Easy Apply positions job seekers can apply for?
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, over 6 million Americans are currently unemployedand that doesnt include the millions more who are underemployed, working part-time involuntarily, or have given up hope entirely.
LinkedIn is one of the last remaining free platforms where people can search for jobs, build networks, and apply without unnecessary barriers. So why, during an ongoing employment crisis, are more roadblocks being added?
People have been out of work for months, some even years. Theyre facing evictions, food insecurity, and mental health struggles. Some are slipping into homelessnessand its not because they arent trying.
 The Easy Apply feature is often the only accessible option for those juggling job searches, survival, and limited resources. Throttling this tool feels like punishing the very people who need support the most.
So I ask:
Why now?
Why limit access?
Why make it harder to get back on our feet?
 To fellow job seekers: Have you noticed this new limitation? How has it affected your ability to apply?
 To LinkedIn: Why add friction to a process meant to create opportunity?
We need more access, not less. More support, not more obstacles.

name: Brittany Johnson

text_content:
How bout some poverty insight today?
All my life, I've hated pancakes. Just didn't like 'em. Could not stand the damn things. It was the syrup. And the butter. Never did like the taste. So for decades, I didn't touch pancakes.
Turns out, the problem was my parents were poor. And when you are poor, you do the best you can to provide for your family.
That Maple Syrup I hated so much that I wouldn't touch anything that had Maple in it? Well, it wasn't really Maple Syrup. It was Mrs. Butterworth's, or whatever knockoff brand Save-a-Lot sells. That "Butter"? Wasn't. It was Crock Pot Margarine, or whatever knockoff brand of that Save-a-Lot sells.
Turns out when you are poor, you can't afford to buy a lot of nice stufflike real, no kidding, fatty foods. That might be something that people like RFK, Jr. and some of these billionaires would do well to remember
I had never tried real Maple Syrup until I got in my 50s. Butter? My 20s. The syrup? No one had ever told me any different. I just assumed that what I had eaten was Maple Syrup, and I wanted nothing to do with it.
Turns out real Maple Syrup? That shit is pretty damn good. Put a little butter--not margarine--on a stack of pancakes? Pour some Canadian Maple Syrup over that? It is no better than sex. But on certain days--it approaches it.
And yes, I know someone is going to chime in and say, "But I Love MRS. Butterworth!" All fine and dandy. But there is a big difference in choosing to like Mrs. Butterworth, Vienna Sausage, Potted Meat, Bologna, Deer Meat, or Fudge Rounds, and that being the only kind of stuff one can afford.
Might do people well to consider that before they complain about all the unhealthy food choices poor people make....
#snap #foodstamps #RFK #health #junkfood #poverty #entitlement

name: Jamie M.

name: Stephanie Heizmann, CPA
headline: Founder, NumbersAI  Know Your Nu...
text_content:
Would We Need to Rewrite the Bible If Poverty Ended?
I once asked a young priest something thats stayed with me for years:
"If we ever solved poverty  if there were no poor left  would we need to rewrite the Bible?"
Because so much of scripture is about human purpose, morality, and justice, in one form or another, has been woven into the economic, social, and spiritual framework since civilization began.
Today, economist define poverty in numbers 
 Globally: less than $3 a day (World Bank's latest line)
 In the U.S.: below $31,200 a year for a family of four
 A true living wage: often $60,000$100,000 depending on location & family size
So if technology, automation, and Universal Basic Income ever truly eradicated material scarcity... what would become of the verses that told us to feed the poor, clothe the needy, or care for the least among us?
Would they become obsolete?
Or reinterpret them as calls to build systems that prevent poverty from ever returning?
Maybe Proverbs 19:17 ("Whoever is kind to the poor lends to the LORD...") would evolve into:
"Where every need is met, generosity becomes gratitude for the common good."
Maybe faith without works (James 2:1517) would remind us:
"True faith sustains fairness  ensuring want never returns."
In a world where AI and automation can create abundance, the new moral question isnt how to feed the poor...
Its how to use abundance wisely  to restore purpose, meaning, and equality in a post-scarcity society.
Because perhaps the true "rewrite" isn't of scripture, but of ourselves.
#Poverty #UBI #FaithAndEconomics #FutureOfWork #AI #Sustainability #Ethics #Philosophy #LivingWage #Humanity #Leadership #LinkedInThoughts

name: Cyndi Joiner
headline: Board Member | Strategic Advisor | Men...
text_content:
We just returned from #Kenya and the graduation of 30 high school seniors from Good Samaritan School (GSS) in #Birikani. We celebrated academic achievements and honored GSSs teachers for their role in shaping the lives of these students.
The road to an education is not easy for these kids. Remote villages have challenges like #poverty, family related #gender #based #violence and #sexual #abuse. One of the students, Ishmael, whom we have sponsored for a decade, is an orphan who has struggled with severe loneliness. His graduation was so gratifying, and his expression conveyed confidence and humility. Ishmaels experience reflects that of many GSS students, who rely on two hot meals daily provided by the school to avoid hunger.
#Education is considered a gift for children in Kenya, yet more than 3 million may never have this opportunity. Watching our GSS students cross the stage, receive their diploma, and discover their unique voice demonstrates the importance of investing and nurturing #Character, regardless of a childs circumstances. GSS stands out as a beacon of #hope, opening doors for dreams to be realized, teaching faith-based principles, and providing spiritual guidance.
Retouch founders Chris and Jennifer Hadsell and the Board thank our Global Partners for their support in creating lasting impact for future generations.
#ChangingLives #BuildingCharacter #ItTakesAVillage #BetterTogether

text_content:

Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce
Why We Champion Our Members: Building Our Own Table

At the Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce, our mission has always been clear: to advance economic growth and create sustainable pathways for Black-owned businesses and non profits to thrive. Today, I want to speak directly and plainly about why we promote our DBCC members so intentionally, and why we urge our community to spend their dollars with them.

For generations, mainstream corporations have received the majority of our consumer spending, often without reinvesting back into our neighborhoods. While they profit, our small businesses, our innovators, our job creators, our community builders, fight twice as hard for visibility, resources, and economic opportunity.

That's why we choose to spotlight, celebrate, and elevate our members.

DBCC members are more than businesses, they are the heartbeat of Dallas' Black commerce. They create local jobs, support local families, and infuse our culture through service, products, and integrity. When you support a DBCC member, dollars circulate right here at home, strengthening our ecosystem from the inside out.

Starting today, we'll be showcasing our incredible DBCC members across your timelines and inboxesnot just for you not only to know who they are, but to support thembuy their products, use their services, and share their businesses with others.

As the holiday season approaches, remember that these businesses aren't just names on a list. They are the heartbeat of our neighborhoods and the reason our communities continue to thrive.

Thank you for choosing to uplift and invest in our members!

This isn't just about buying Black. It's about building a future where our businesses stand strong without waiting for validation from mainstream corporations.

Let's make intentional decisions.
Let's invest in the entrepreneurs who invest in us.
Let's make sure our dollars reflect our values.

Spend with DBCC businesses. Support our members. Strengthen our community.

 Harrison Blair
President, Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce

name: Anita Mrs. P . P.
headline: Greatness  | Coach | Curriculum Devel...
text_content:
AI Is My Bestie... But Let Me Tell You Why That Matters.

One thing about me: I'm going to show up as my authentic self.

And the older I get, the more I  refuse to #code-switch to make other people comfortable.

Yesterday, I had a moment where I asked my #AI assistant for help refining a message. But what I realized is this... even AI will shift your tone based on the type of prompt you give it.

Say it softly, and it gives you soft.
Say it direct, and it gives you direct.
Say it boldly, and it gives you bold.

But here's the part that hit me:

If I'm not careful, I could accidentally code-switch my own voice through the prompts I write.

And as a #Black #woman, that #awareness mattered to me.

Because for years, we've been told to soften ourselves. To tone down. To package our truth. To make sure we don't come across as too strong, too confident, too direct, too honest.

But #authenticity is clarity.
Authenticity builds #trust.
Authenticity is #alignment.

So I had to remind myself:

I don't need to dilute who I am to communicate effectively. 

I can be warm, direct, truthful, and powerful all at the same time.

And if someone misreads my intention after I've been clear, that is not my burden.

What I love about using AI is that it reflects right back to me what I put in. It showed me that when I lead with authenticity, the output will follow suit.

So here's my takeaway:

Whether it's AI, #work, #leadership, or relationships... give the world the real you. Not the edited you. Not the palatable version. The aligned version.

Because when you show up fully as yourself, people always know how to meet you.

And that is the most powerful brand of all.

Go be Great,
 Mrs. P

I recently wrote about what it means to be #Black, #Autistic, and navigating systems that were never built with us in mind, from childhood and diagnosis to therapy and community care.

This piece reflects the intersections I hold as a therapist, facilitator, and Black autistic person, and why creating culturally specific, neurodivergent-affirming spaces is essential for real healing.

If you work in mental health, education, DEI, youth services, or community work, I hope this perspective expands how we see "support," "advocacy," and "safety"especially for Black autistic folks who are often unseen or misdiagnosed.

Therapy, community, and care get better for everyone when they intentionally include us.

Also starting a few autistic groups come January, If you know anyone that might be interested please feel free to reach out by DM or email! Wanting to read the longer post, you can find it here! https://lnkd.in/ew3m3-TA

name: Corrie Jo Biddle
headline: Talent Leader | Workplace Culture & Inc...
text_content:
#WhereAreYou on #DEI?: One of the hardest things I have ever done is talent work in the current political environment.
Because the work is personal...even when I don't want it to be.

To me, #diversity, #equity, and #inclusion are natural words. But to some people they are. To some people they are divisive words. And to some they land as divisive and a form of discrimination.

The work is challenging (and interesting) for me because every person has a different relationship with it and a different lens on it.

For me, it is personal because I am a #Black #Woman.

And as much as I want people to care about DEI the way that I do, and for the reasons that I do, I know that is not really ever going to be the case. That's tough, because the stakes feel higher for someone like me.

I believe #TheStakesAreHigh for everyone.

It may just take longer for some people to lose sleep over it the way many of us already do. And even then, the reason why it matters to them might be completely different from mine.

Some people care about this work because they want to strengthen the #economic #viability of the region. Some care because they want communities where their #children can thrive. Some care about #access to jobs and #promotions without identity being a barrier. Some are focused on growing the #bottom #line by expanding into new market segments. The list goes on, and sometimes I wonder if it matters how or why we get there. Or if the most important thing is simply that we get there. And if that is true, what does #there look like for Milwaukee?

These conversations don't flow as easily as they did a couple years ago, because it feels more easy than ever to say the #wrong #thing. But I wonder how people are quietly feeling about the shift (or the lack of one) from DEI language to #inclusion and #belonging. My friend Daniel Terrio, M.S. reminded me that this work used to be called #tolerance. Remember that? So the shifts are not new, and they probably are not over.

So, indeed I'm curious. #How #are #you #feeling about all of this? What would you like to see from #employers, #elected officials, and #community #leaders and your #networks? What questions are you sitting with? What makes you mad or relieved? Where could you use a sounding board or a thinking partner? And would you feel comfortable exploring this in a town hall style conversation? If you'd rather send me private message, that's welcomed too.

name: Elizabeth McCoy, Rest...
headline: Black Women Hire Me To Help Them Pu...
text_content:
Strength is something Black women rarely lack.

But what's missing, and what many of us are quietly crying for, is real support.

Support that doesn't just applaud us for carrying it all... but actually helps us put something down.

Here are 4 ways we can start showing up for each other better:

1 Assume the Best of Each Other
Too often, comparison creates distance. Support looks like grace, choosing to see your sister through a lens of love instead of suspicion.

2 Celebrate Loudly, Not Quietly
Silent claps don't break systems. Repost the win, speak the name in rooms, remind her that her success strengthens all of us.

3 Create Soft Landing Spaces
Being "the strong one" is glorified, but rarely do we have places to be soft. Support means saying, "You don't have to be the introduction. Move from "I hope you win" to "Here's how we can win together."

4 Share Access, Not Just Advice
Advice is easy. Access changes lives. Send the job link. Make the introduction. Move from "I hope you win" to "Here's how we can win together."

^^ Because being strong isn't the issue. It's being strong alone that's breaking us.

Which of these speaks to you most right now?

#Blackwomen #Supportblackwomen #Black #LeadershipWithCare #RestReclaimRise #BlackWomenInLeadership #EmotionalWellness #AbundanceMindset #DynastisWealth #SupportEachOther #CommunityCare #Heal

We are here to #Disrupt, to #Uplift, and to bring #visibility to those too long left on #TheMargins of tech and #legacy.

+++++

#OurRoadmap isn't just a timelineit's a #testament.

Each phase is a promise that we are moving from #DiscoveryToDestiny, from #wireframes to a world where #Black and #multiculturalgenius is not an afterthought, but the headline.

+++++

Phase 1: We listen.
We gather #stories, #dreams, #painpointsthe real data of #OurPeople.

Phase 2: We #prototype Possibility.
No vision too #bold, no interface too beautiful.

Phase 3: #WeBuild the bones.
#UserProfiles. #Feeds. #Notifications. #Infrastructure.
Because power without structure is just noise.

+++++

Phase 4: We launch the Beta. Public. Proud. Unapologetic.
Ambassadors lead, the world listens.

Phase 5:
- #WeGoLive.
- #FullFeature.
- #FullForce.

+++++

Phase 6: We scale.
#Stories, live streams, new forums, new worlds.

+++++

#Monetization for US, by us. Global expansionbecause the world is hungry for a platform without gatekeepers.

This is not a sprint.
It is not a mere app launch.

+++++

This is the quiet #revolution we've been promised but rarely delivered.

I ask you:
Who gets to tell your story?

Today, we reclaim the pen.

Join #TheMovement.
Build #TheLegacy.

Spotted this mysterious beauty at FRIM, Kepong.

Always a thrill to encounter the black bat flowerone of nature's rare dark blooms.

Known scientifically as Tacca chantrieri, this exotic species is native to Southeast Asia and belongs to the yam family (Dioscoreaceae).

Its dramatic, bat-shaped flowers range from deep purple to velvety black, stretching up to 12 inches across. The long, whisker-like bractssometimes reaching 28 inchesgive it an otherworldly charm.

Thriving in the shaded understory of humid tropical forests, the black bat flower is a quiet spectacle.

name: Jocelyn McGinnis
headline: Senior Software Engineer AI R&D @ Wel...
text_content:
New Series!  Watch me produce fungal melanin & demo its insane radiation-blocking power!

So many of you asked for this after my last series on pulluan - well, here it is!

What you're seeing in the photos is a preview of a three month long adventure to see if I could ferment pure fungal DHN (1,8-dihydroxynaphthalene) MELANIN pigment and demonstrate its ability to block UV radiation.

We've known from years of research that melanin has a unique property of being able to block all kinds of radiation, like UV and ionizing radiation - making it a key candidate for shielding experience in space. This is significant as we look to fungi to provide new solutions to protect us from the effects of space travel - and here on earth, where safe and natural sunblock products are much needed.

Over the next several posts, I'm going to walk you through all the trail & error it took for me to get to this stage, including:
* Preparing liquid culture of Aureobasidium pullulans
* Fermenting several liters of media
* Acid / base extraction of the melanin
* Generating a melanin film for the UV experiment
* Finally, demonstrating UV blocking ability using UV-sensitive cyanotype paper

Be sure to like this post and follow me so you don't miss the updates! I'll post the link to the next update in the comments.

Speaking of comments - let me know what you think about this series idea and share with me what you know about melanin and all its possible uses!

#radiation #fungi #mycology #research #mushrooms #melanin #black #science #research #space #spacetravel #engineering #experiment #pullulan #chemistry #biology #biotech #fermentation #chemistry #naturalproducts #dna #pigment #softwareengineering #swe

text_content:
A few years ago, I realized I'm not just building #wealth. I'm building a #blueprint for what freedom looks like in Black.

Not borrowed #freedom that depends on someone else's permission. Not performative freedom that smiles for #instagram but panics when the rent is due.

I'm talking about rooted, #generational, unapologetic, blood-in-the-soil freedom.

The kind that doesn't flinch when the storms come, because it was built on rock, not reputation.

Freedom that includes a will and a witness. An #estate #plan and a lineage. Order. Faith in #God and fidelity to the #financial details.

Because sustainable freedom doesn't happen by chance. It happens by strategy.

I'm building for Black families who've carried too much and inherited too little.

This is what freedom looks like in Black:
#Strategic. #Spiritual. #Sustainable.

And every plan I create is a love letter to a future we were never supposed to reach but will.

It's not for applause. It's not for likes.

It's for the #babies I may never meet so they'll know what security feels like, not just what it costs.

This is what freedom looks like in Black:
#Strategic. #Spiritual. #Sustainable.

And every plan I create is a love letter to a future we were never supposed to reach but will.

Hi, I'm Dr. Nicole B. Simpson, a CFP, Legacy planner. I specialize in financial trauma. I help people rebuild their economic lives. This work is about strategy, healing, and truth. It's about learning how to invest wisely, build real legacy, and move through money without fear.

If that's the conversation you're ready for, you'll find it on the podcast.

text_content:
Hey! Good afternoon,

I am thrilled to share the conversation I had with the brilliant Ilana Henry, creator and producer of The Starfish Storytellers, about the importance of inclusive storytelling. We talked about bias (yes, we all have them!), deepening character development, writing outside one's own race, my work with clients, and the value of a sensitivity review.

I could have chatted for hours more! I love my work. I love assisting writers to tell better stories.

I think that comes across clearly in this interview, now available on Bedford TV (Bedford Community Access Television, Inc)'s YouTube channel: https://lnkd.in/eytyxa_F.

Please check out! And please share it with your writer friends and literary communities.

If you or anyone you know needs a sensitivity review, just let me know.

To learn more about my work: https://lnkd.in/gBrGUUUN

Thank you!
BE SAFE

name: Greta Fobbs
headline: Building a Legacy of Loyalty, Engageme...
text_content:
"Unhireable" at Facebook.
#Unstoppable as a #Founder.

Here's the #Data... 
...and the #Receipts.   

+++++

Let me take you back to 2016.
Facebook HQ, Menlo Park.
#CommunityOperationsTeam.

I was in the buildingliterally and figurativelybuilding pages, running campaigns, launching projects, and watching the platform evolve from the inside.

They handed out free ad credits.
I ran campaigns.
My playbook was straight from the Silicon Valley manual.

On paper, I was the kind of Black talent they said they wanted in tech: innovative, collaborative, a builder.

But when it came time to hire for real roles, to get decision-making power, to move beyond the surface?

I got hit with that label:
Unhireable.

No concrete reason. No feedback worth anything.
Just the polite not a fit, the coded language so many of us know too well.

Let's call it what it is:
#SystemicBias, dressed up in HR jargon...

#TheData Doesn't Lie
Black talent = 13% of the U.S. population, but only 4% at big tech companies.

Inside Facebook/Meta, Black employees still struggle to move beyond entry-level roles. In 2024, Meta reported Black representation in U.S. tech roles at just 2.6%up only slightly from when I was there.

More than half of Black tech professionals say they've experienced microaggressions, lack of mentorship, or been passed over for promotions...

Yet the world keeps asking:
Why aren't there more #BlackFounders?

Because we built the system, only to find out it was never built for us.

Receipts?
You Want Proof?
Here's a screenshot for you: My Meta business account?
Disabled. For years.

I didn't get banned for breaking rulesI just became invisible when I stopped serving the machine.

But let's be clear:
That's proof, not a defeat.

Every follower, every campaign, every story I've built since then is organic.
No paid ads. No backdoor hacks.
Just real people, real value, real movement.

From Locked Doors to Blueprint Building

I realized early:
If you're always fighting for a seat at the table, maybe you need to build a new table.

So I did.

--> Google Greg Fobbs.
--> See HiveWire Tribe.
--> Look up BlackUnicorn Ventures.

We are the proof that you don't need permission to lead.
We are building the future of technologyand doing it globally.

HiveWire Tribe is connecting entrepreneurs and builders across five #continents.

#BlackUnicornVentures is investing in talent that the system keeps overlooking.

We've been verified by Google, recognized on every major search engineall without a single dollar spent on #paidmarketing.

This Is #TheNewBlueprint
If the old system only knows how to lock you out, it's time to build something better.

Meta can disable my account, but they can't stop my #legacy, my family, my community, or my impact.

To every #Black and #MulticulturalFounder who's been told you're  #unhireable:

 You are not invisible.
 You are not alone.
 You are inevitable.

name: Shawna L.
headline: Problem Solver/Entrepreneur / Logistics/ Fixer...
text_content:
" WHY ARE BLACK AND LATINO/HISPANIC STUDENTS STILL BEING PLACED ON THE BACK BURNERS?"

Harvard University has recently been accused of violating civil-rights laws
Epecifically Title VIby failing to protect #Jewish and #Israeli students.

The U.S. Department of Education and Department of Justice, under the #Trump administration, found Harvard displayed deliberate indifference toward #antisemitic harassment related to the Israel/Hamas conflict

As a result, Harvard now risks the loss of federal funding unless it enacts immediate reforms

But this issue shouldn't be confined to #Jewish students

I'm writing this as someone whose family has graduated from #Princeton and #Yale, and some other Ivy League schools,
Ivy League schools have faced micro-aggressions, overt racism, and dismissive faculty and peers

These aren't rare anecdotes, they're part of a broader legacy

Harvard's I, Too, Am Harvard campaign showcased how #Black undergraduate students often felt #isolated, #uncomfortable, or outright #excluded on campus

Latino students in K-12 recounted teachers who refused to let them speak Spanish or subtly discriminated against them
aft.org

Faculty cases, such as the denial of tenure for prominent scholars like Lorgia Garca Pea in 2019, raised major concerns about bias within the institution
NATIONALREVIEW.COM

And please let us not forget the nooses ties around Black faculty doors at the #prestigious #COLUMBIA #UNIVERSITY

There's what needs to happen:

1. A truly intersectional civil-rights commitment

Harvard isn't just under legal scrutiny for antisemitism; it faced bipartisan pressure under both Trump and Biden administrations for failing to respond effectively to Jewish students' concerns
washingtonpost.com

But the missing piece is a holistic approach

Policies and oversight that protect ALL #minorities, religious, racial, and ethnic

2. Equitable enforcement of Title VI and related policies.
The Louis Brandeis Center's lawsuit noted Harvard inconsistently applied its anti-harassment policies, addressing some groups more forcefully than others
en.wikipedia.org

That must change

Every report, whether it comes from #Jewish, #Muslim, #Black, #Hispanic, or #Asian students, must trigger clear, transparent, and timely action

Harvard should not just support these voices, but listen proactively by holding regular town halls, increasing reporting transparency, and hiring ombuds for equity

But only if the university embraces equity in #full ensuring that civil-rights protections are universal, not #selective

#HARVARD #Columbiauniversity #Inclusion #Futureleaders #Civilrights #Hispanic #Asian #education #Futureleaders #civilrights #protection #presidenttrump #linkedin #linkedinvoice

name: Jocelyn Dodds, M.Ed
headline: District Director | Diversity, Equity, inclu...
text_content:
The USDA saying it has "sufficiently addressed historic discrimination" against Black farmers is flat out wrong.

In 1920, Black farmers owned 14% of U.S. farmland. Today, it's less than 1%. That didn't happen by accident. It happened because of decades of systemic discrimination, including denied loans and lack of access to resources.

Even as recent as 2022, only 36% of Black farmer loan applications were approved compared to 72% for white farmers.

Lawsuits like Pigford proved discrimination exists, and while billions were paid in settlements, the structural problems still exist.

Removing the term "socially disadvantaged" and cutting targeted support doesn't mean racism has been fixed, it just makes it harder to track and address.

This isn't progress. It's a rollback disguised as resolution.
Don't fall for it.
